There weren't any special programs for kids, but we did see other families there. For NYC, a nice sized Queen suite gave us everything we needed. Didn't use the kitchen for our overnight stay but definitely would in the future. Rooms were comfortable (ok... a little tight at the foot of the bed but not like some complaints described), the amenities were really appreciated, e.g., free wifi, Keurig coffee service in room, desk area, energy efficient rooms (you put your room card in a device that controls the electricity to save energy while you're out). Lovely bathrooms (although they need a hand towel holder), but really comfortable. We are a family of 3 so the kiddo slept on the pull-out sofa. Room was in good condition-- it appears that shade of green must be the theme, but its nice. The bellman held our luggage after checkout to allow us to stay in the city and not have to worry about our bags. Parking garage is right around the corner -- very close. Viand diner downstairs was OK for dinner -- not great but sufficient. Friendly front desk folks were really helpful -- have breakfast at Bagel Talk not too far away. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 4.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cSuperb hotel and a Proposal!\u201d", "text": "My partner and I went on holiday to NYC on 27/10/12 (the day before Hurricane Sandy!!!!) and booked to stay at the Hotel Beacon. After reading previous reviews on here it was recommended that we emailed in advance to request a high corner room away from the lifts. I did choose to email in advance as I also wanted to inform the hotel that I was planning to propose to my girlfriend. I received a swift response from the reservations department and they were very polite. \nUpon arrival, our room wasn't ready (we were two hours early) but the staff were very friendly and informative. They recommend a few local shops and food places if we wanted to pass the time. When we arrived back after just over an hour the room was ready and we were allocated a room on the 21st floor (there is only 25 floors in the hotel). I do not cope well with confined spaces etc but the speed of the lifts was excellent and I managed to survive the constant use! :). We arrived at our room and it appeared we had been given a larger room (possibly because I emailed in advance) and we also received a complimentary bottle of wine and box of chocolates which was a lovely touch. The room was excellent, large, spacious, very clean with more than enough storage. The views from our huge window were fantastic! The concierge were attentive and informative without being pushy (this was my partners 6th time in NYC and they did not feel the need to tell her anything as she had good local knowledge). \nEven though NYC pretty much shut down for a few days, the housekeeping service was still available (albeit on a reduced staff) and they were very polite. If you are there for a few nights (we were for 5) I would recommend that on your first morning to leave a $10 dollar tip and a note to housekeeping then leave $2/$3 for the duration of your stay and you will end up with plenty of extra toiletries/towels/pillows etc or anything else you may need. \nThe hotel staff kept all guests up to date with information regarding local facilities that were still available during the hurricane. \nWe were both very impressed with Hotel Beacon and the staff and will certainly be planning on staying there again when we visit again next year. It is extremely popular with a wide variety of ages and people visiting for various reasons. I highly recommend the Hotel Beacon.\nP.S. my partner agreed to marry me when I proposed! This hotel is a block from the subway, clean, clean, clean and best of all for NYC, QUIET. The front desk was extremely helpful and we will stay here again. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 3.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 4.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cBest View I've EVER had!\u201d", "text": "I chose this hotel because it is the closest hotel to my old apartment. I moved out of NY a year ago, and miss it terribly. I wanted to be right back where I used to live. I was a little hesitant about the Beacon, because I had been in there years ago. And I mean over 20 years ago, and it wasn't very nice. But it has REALLY changed!!! It's VERY nice!!! Let me break it down from the big picture to the small details.\nLocation: Perfect for me. I love the Upper West Side. I spend most of my time in Central Park (walking, photographing, running, bird watching, people watching, going to the zoo, bike riding, exploring, etc). My goal when I lived in NY was to live as close to Fairway (a unique grocery store) as humanly possible. The Beacon is right across the street. And the Beacon has kitchens in each room, so I actually did buy food at Fairway and prepared it in my room. But back to the location description. 75th and Broadway is the epicenter of 3 amazing cupcake shops, a famous bakery, Fairway, Zabars, Juice Generation (great smoohties), Harry's Burritos, Big Nicks, Shake Shack, the Park, three excellent gyms and a couple great yoga places. If your vacation plans don't revolve around food and exercise, you'll think that list was strange. But for me, it was perfect. It was like being home. I should also mention Lincoln Center and the Natural History museum are very close by. All the museums on the East Side are walkable through the park. If you're more into the downtown scene/night life or Broadway, maybe it's not for you. But hey, the subway is RIGHT THERE, so transportation is convenient.\nHotel: The lobby, staff, elevators were all superior for a non-brand hotel.\nHallways: Carpeted, fairly quiet, wide and clean.\nRooms. Bright, clean, newly remodeled, spacious, welcoming, pleasing finishes, comfortable. Each room (as far as I know) has a kitchen (with dishes/pots and pans),a safe, tv, free wifi, extra blankets, good toiletries, ironing board, luggage rack, comfortable beds and pillows. Our room was amazing. It was room 2112, on the 21st floor. It was a corner room with a view I could NOT keep my eyes off of. One window faced Central Park and the East side. One faced downtown. We had views of Times Square, The Chrysler Building, Broadway (the street) and the Ansonia-which is a gorgeous building, and on the East, views of some of my very favorite architecture (the San Remo!), Citicorp, the Sherry Netherland and that glorious Park. We slept with the blinds open. We watched the sun rise over the buildings, We couldn't stop looking or taking pictures. I had lived in NY 10 years, in many apartments, and I never had a view like that. \nBTW there were also windows in the kitchen and Bathroom.The one in the bathroom opened.\nI will ALWAYS stay at this hotel when I'm in NY. {"ratings": {"overall": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cGood but should be better\u201d", "text": "We spent four nights in New York at the Beacon Hotel. We had a quite large suite with a large sitting room, a large bedroom and a fullsize bathroom. After five weeks in European hotels we really appreciated the space.\nThe decor throughout the hotel is understated and the facilities are very limited (no gym, no pool, no breakfast). {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 4.0, "overall": 4.0, "value": 4.0, "location": 4.0, "sleep_quality": 3.0, "rooms": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cStaying at the Beacon with Kids\u201d", "text": "We stayed at the Beacon for 11 days in August 2012 as part of a sightseeing trip to New York. I was travelling with my two children (aged 12 and 8) so our needs are a bit different to when we are travelling as a whole family. The Beacon worked well for us - its more than a hotel room with a bit more space and the location is excellent as it just ten minutes away from the action, but not in a touristy area, so you feel like you are actually living in New York as oppose to holidaying. The beds were a bit smaller than I expected - I would say the two beds are more like King singles than doubles so it was a bit of a squash with an adult and a child in one bed and definitely would not work for two adults that need space. However the rooms are well laid out and have everything you need. Housekeeping is good and unlike others we had no problems with bugs or anything of that nature. The sitting room is of a good size and a welcome respite at the end of a busy day to be able to stock the fridge with a few drinks and chill without having to order room service etc. The area has plenty of nice local eateries (so cheap for someone coming from Australia) and the proximity to Central Park is a lovely walking/running start to any day. We did not eat in but there is a tiny kitchen with microwave and small cooker, so if you wanted to it would be practical to have light meals. There is a laundry on the 7th floor which is great especially as I put some laundry with the concierge on the first day and it call came back dry cleaned - even t shirts!! So having access to the laundry is great with kids etc. The rooms are also very reasonably priced for New York and the staff really helpful. Its not the sort of place if you are looking for a couples break with facilities on hand but if you are looking for a family hotel with more space than a hotel room, this is perfect. The staff are also very helpful in securing cabs, posting things, and generally helping. Check in was easy and the staff were friendly. The rooms are large for New York but awkward. {"ratings": {"overall": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cAbsolutely Brilliant\u201d", "text": "I had done my research before booking the Hotel Beacon through Virgin Holidays. On our last stay in NY 18 years ago we had also booked a suite with kitchenette - tho located mid town. It is a great solution if you want to keep flexibility as to how & when you eat and can keep costs down too. \nWe arrived to a very friendly welcome from the reception staff and an immaculate room on the 18th floor looking East towards Central Park. The air conditioning was very efficient - it was really hot and sticky when we arrived. The room had everything that we needed - a big plus being the super fast free WiFi. As others have commented, the Fairway supermarket opposite has everything you need for stay. We did our own breakfasts but the Beacon is superbly located for great eating - especially all the eateries a few blocks North on Amsterdam Ave. \nThe hotel was always busy but we had no problems with noise from either inside or outside. Those rooms that have the Broadway view would be room numbered around 07, 08, and so on.\nIt did have a very generous sized bedroom with a King bed with a very comfortable mattress. Plenty of hanging provision and drawers for clothing. In a cupboard was a coded safe, ironing board (with iron) and more hanging space for jackets. It also has a kitchenette, with a sofa (with fold out bed), desk and very small dining table.\nHowever, as we were staying with friends who were also in another King room in 602, these corner rooms (01) had a better floor plan than the room next door. \nOur children slept in the fold out bed, it did obviously decrease the floor space in the room, when out, but there was still plenty of room to get around.\nThe kitchenette, has a microwave, four burner cook top including oven, sink, and decent sized fridge. There was no detergent, cleaning implements etc - housekeeping will wash your dishes for you when they make up the room in the morning. You could buy this stuff if you wanted to.\nThere is no pool at this property.\nProperty location is near W74th Street on Broadway. It is about two blocks away from Central Park. (Dakota building is nearby).\nThe property is either an express subway ride to 42nd street (Times Square) or a about a 5 stop travel. Easy to navigate. Staff at the respective subway areas very helpful.\nOverall I found the property to be a bit far out of the epicentre of all the attractions downtown, but it is not that much of a detraction.\nStaff at the property extremely nice and helpful. \nNearby to the propery is (as other reviews have outlined) a market across the road, which has all of your shopping needs. Next door is a cafe, which does very nice meals and there are an abundance of other restaurant options nearby to satsify all needs. \nThe Beacon Theatre is next door and there are plenty of shows that play here that may be of interest to people. Not stage shows. When we were here, Seal was an upcoming act.\nWe booked this property on booking.com. We had no issues using this site for the property. However, although booking.com outlines the online price does not include taxes (having used it before I was aware of this) but the local taxes for property in NYC is astronomical. \nOur tarriff with booking.com was $365 per night (reasonable for NYC with the ammenties and location we were told), however when checking out, we had in excess of $300 added in NYC tax, NY State tax and local tax. I printed off some maps before our trip and found them very helpful while we were there!\nWe ate at the Cafe Viand next door a few times - we had breakfast and dinner there. They charged per pound (I think it was $6.99 per pound) and that was enough for a meal or two! They had good selection of meat, fish, vegetables, rice and potatoes with different varieties presented each day. All of good quality, very tasty and saved us quite a bit of money. It was also very convenient, especially as we had a small kitchenette and dining area where we could eat our take away back at the hotel. They also catered for those with food allergies, stocking many wheat, gluten and dairy free items.\nCentral park was within walking distance and we decided to take a short ride in a horse and carriage on our last day. Our room was on the 16th floor on the front side of the hotel. The view was absolutely delightful. Hotel service was efficient and unobtrusive. The staff was very quick to respond whenever we asked for assistance. Our room had a small kitchenette with a microwave oven and this proved to be useful for a quick breakfast or light dinner at the end of the day. But then again, there are plenty of eating places within walking distance from the hotel, so cooking can be pretty much off the agenda when you're staying here. Still, if you do want to cook, you can get all your groceries from the market across the road. The hotel does not have any dining facilities, but there is a Cafe right next door. We went there for brunch on a Sunday, and it was packed full of New Yorkers presumably those living nearby. This hotel would have to be pretty much high up on our selection list. The rates are in the mid range and if I really do need to be picky, the room is a little on the small side, and in our case, a little tired and dated e.g small bathroom, cracked grouting - and I am still not sure about the pastel green walls and furniture. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cExcellent hotel in a great neighbourhood.\u201d", "text": "Chose this hotel as the best review in our budget on Trip Advisor. Great idea as it was an excellent choice. Staff were courteous, friendly and helpful. Hotel is clean and well decorated with a nod to Art Deco style. The rooms were spacious and comfortable with good American style tubs and shower over, fully marble tiled, amazing beds and very well equipped kitchenettes, with crockery, cutlery etc for the number of occupants. The photographs on the web site were very accurate (a rare thing on hotel websites I find) and if anything didn't do the rooms justice in terms of space and comfort. Complimentary tea bags and coffee pods for the coffee machine were provided each day As the hotel is right across the street from the incredible Fairway market, which is open 6 am till 1 am., we made full use of the catering facilities. Also there is a fast cheap clean launderette on site on the 7th floor and free use of computers printers and internet in a room off the lobby. Don't be fooled by the hotel's three star rating as this is probably down to the fact that it has no restaurant, bar or pool. This is a plus in that it is quiet, but also not a disadvantage because of the aforementioned Fairway, and also Cafe Viand downstairs which is a real New York neighbourhood diner and will even do roomservice to the Beacon if asked. It is a great safe neighbourhood to walk about in with lots of great bars and restaurants, a subway station with both express and local trains, within walking distance of Central Park, and with some iconic New York buildings nearby. The Ansonia is across the street, and on the corner of the next block is the Apple Bank, which is an old New York savings bank and worth a look inside for the amazing unspoilt decor. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cBrilliant hotel - cannot recommend it enough!\u201d", "text": "We stayed at the Beacon in December of 2011 as we were getting married! first thing to note was the ever lovely Ken who is the doorman! He is genuinely kind & everytime he sees you, remembers what you are up to & asks how your day was. The staff at the front desk were very helpful upon check in & after cheekily asking if we could be upgraded & unfortunately being told the hotel was full, the wonderful receptionist said if we were willing to wait a little while, they could put us in a king room on the 25th (top!) floor! The room has a little kitchenette - which to be honest, we only really used the fridge from. {"ratings": {"service": 2.0, "cleanliness": 4.0, "overall": 2.0, "value": 4.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 3.0}, "title": "\u201cGreat Location - odd maintenance\u201d", "text": "I traveled with family (one adult, one senior, and one teenager), and this could not have been a better location. It was so close to the subway and the park, and the store across the street was great as well. There was a lot of space in the room, and it was nicely appointed with a fold-out couch, small kitchen, small safe, and ample storage. The one downfall was the maintenance of the building. There was a hole over our door for four days of our visit (perhaps an air vent should have gone in this location, but it was just a gaping square). On our last morning around 6 am, the drilling, cutting, and hammering started. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 3.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cAmazing value and location!\u201d", "text": "After many hours trawling through Trip Advisor reviews, we decided to book our 7 nights in NYC at Hotel Beacon. We were not disappointed! \nWe found the Trip Advisor reviews to be accurate and fair. We booked a one bedroom suite (Room 1802) to share between four adults (all in our mid to late 20s - a married couple and two friends), which comfortably provided all of us with heaps of space and privacy. As reflected in the earlier reviews, the bathroom was small, but very clean and had very (!) strong water pressure. The room was very clean and fairly recently refurbished (we requested a newly refurbished room on an upper floor overlooking Broadway and our request was met). There was heaps of closet space and the kitchenette was ideal. As others have mentioned, the in-room wi-fi was quite expensive, so we didn't pay to have it. However, with a Starbucks literally on every other corner offering free wi-fi and a few computers in the Lobby with free wi-fi, we don't think we would have used it even if we had of purchased it.\nIn our view, the hotel is perfectly located on the corner of 75th and Broadway on the Upper West Side. It is a great neighbourhood which while quieter than Midtown or Downtown (which is exactly what we were after \u2013 we all agreed that we would have hated to have stayed anywhere near the crush of Times Square!) still had loads of cafes, restaurants and shopping all within walking distance (we recommend Big Nick\u2019s Burgers on Broadway one block up from the hotel, Blondies Sports Bar, Red Velvet cupcakes on 72nd Street and the Wine Bar on 72nd Street after Columbus). As other reviews have mentioned, there are two fantastic grocer / deli / supermarkets directly across the road, which we made full use of! We felt like true New Yorkers by the end of our trip!\nI am a single female traveller and I felt completely safe walking around the neighbourhood by myself at night as well as catching the subway by myself to our stop at night (the Red 1, 2 and 3 lines all go Down Town to the main attractions and all stop at 72nd street, so it was really easy to get around \u2013 get the unlimited pass if you are there for a week, we found it was great value). \nThe staff at the hotel were very helpful and friendly for NYC. The fold out mattress in the sofa was very uncomfortable on our first night, so we asked for an upgrade the next morning. The tipping and gratuity applications are a BIG SCAM, so beware! It's set up so you over tip and wont realize until it's too late. The waiters would bring out the bill at the end of our meal and then run our credit cards and come back with an entirely different amount and it would literally take several minutes to figure out what the hell they were charging and how much because it's all in the fine print! We finally figured out after you give consent to run your credit card, they tack on a gratuity of anywhere between 15 -25%. BEWARE!!! If you're not paying attention you will end up tipping 30% without realizing it. \nService in Restaurants - In South Beach is terrible. It's all terrible. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 4.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cUnexpected Pleasure\u201d", "text": "Spent two nights at the Beacon Hotel whilst attending a taping of Conan next door at the Beacon Theatre.\nWas very pleased with this hotel - an unexpected pleasure. Normally hotels that run in the low $200 range in New York City are not the kinds of places you want to spend a lot of time or in the best of areas. The Beacon is surely the exception!\nWe arrived via subway - the hotel is about a half-block north of the 72nd street station on the 1-2-3 line. Check-in was swift and efficient and we were able to get a room on the next to top floor. Given the small size of the lobby we were expecting an equally small room. We were very surprised to find a very well apportioned room with lots of amenities: large bed, separate closet, kitchenette with microwave, sink, coffee maker, stove top and refridge. The bathroom was clean and came with a nice assortment of toiletries. Another plus: both the hotel and the location was QUIET - sometimes a hard thing to find in NYC.\nAcross the street is the flagship Fairway Market which is open from 6:00 AM to 1:00 AM. Here you can get an amazing assortment of just about anything - great to stock the refridge in the room (and to take back home with you). There is a caf\u00e9 in the Fairway where we ate breakfast each day: fresh and organic food.\nI've not spent much time in the upper west side; within blocks of the hotel we found numerous restaurants and assorted shops. And unlike other places in NYC we didn't feel uncomfortable walking around at midnight in this neighbourhood. Given the close proximity to the subway and location on Broadway would highly recommend this hotel even for activities located elsewhere in the city. Ha.\nOff we went across the rd to the Fairway to get some snacks.Great shop but hunt around as some bits we found were expensive.But has everything you need.Downstairs from the Beacon is a Cafe.The few days and want to get about quickly use the subways seriously they are easy to use.We got advice from a lovely ticket man.We bought a metrocard between the 3 of us you load on the amount in the machine and you can top it up.The tip is to share one card.Don't buy the cards from the hotel as it works out more than you need to pay.We put 20dollars one card one person goes through then you pass it back to the next and the next.The money comes off for each single fair each time you swipe it.This is totally acceptable and we were advised this is the cheapest way.With this we went to Times sq 3times statue of liberty, macys, empire states building. ground zero.We still had money on it.If you get tickets for the Empire states do a combined one for statue of liberty as well we paid 35dollars for both that includes ferry.Buy these around macys area.Guys in yellow jackets cheaper than guys in blue jackets out empire states.Don't listen when they tell you its poor visibility up the empire states.Its a way of getting you to get a helicopter trip.\nI could go on and on about New York.But in 3 days we saw a lot so here are a few tips.\n1.Use the subway by the hotel beacon and get a metrocard between your party.\n2.In Macys show your ID at the desk and get 10% discount card.\n3.Use the cafe downstairs for breakfast.\n4.Go to Dallas BBQ restaurant about two blocks back from hotel.Big portions and great place.\n5.Go to Central Park walking distannce from Hotel.\n6.come of Hotel and go right and walk down as many great discounted shops.There is a Make up shop sells many I love this hotel, hard to fault.\nRoom\nOne Bedroom Suite, King Bed, Kitchenette. \nPros\nLocation. I love the UWS. I feel at home here. There are lots of lovely delis and places to eat nearby. The Fairways Market, directly across from the hotel, is an obvious choice, but do wander around. I personally love the West Side Market just a few blocks up from the Hotel (between 76th and 77th). I think they have more options if you want to have dinner in your hotel room.\nBeds: The beds are amazing. The King bed is huge and could fit 3 people in there (hey, watch it! I wasn't going there!)\nKitchenette: Has all you need; plates, cups, bowls, cutlery, toaster, kettle, microwave, fridge (with freezer), gas hob, and a coffee making machine (with lovely French Roast Coffee!)\nCable TV: I know, you didn't come to New York to watch TV but it's nice to have a choice when you do want to laze a little!\nBeacon Theatre next door. Great if you want to catch something on in here.\n72nd Station: The Hotel is but a hop skip and a jump from 72nd Station which is on the express line\nCentral Park: is but a few minutes walk from the hotel and I got some beautiful shots of the Autumnal colours before the freak snow storm came and took down so many wonderful trees \nCons\nNo free Wifi in hotel rooms, I mean come on Hotel Beacon it's time to change! At least give people basic Wifi free of charge and if they want a faster connection, then they pay. Not only does the Beacon boast a fantastic location (love the Upper West Side), but the 2 bedroom suite we booked was perfect for traveling together with friends. Here a quick list of the pros and cons of this solution.\u2028\u2028\nPros: \n\u2028Location - this far up Broadway, the traffic calms down, and the neighborhood fills itself with nice restaurants, 24hour stores, and interesting shops. 2 subway lines are within easy walking distance.\u2028\nRooms - while maintaining a certain degree of old-world charm, the rooms have been nicely redone. Our 2 bedroom suite had one twin room, one king-size bedroom, a living room with a sofabed, 2 bathrooms, and a small kitchen facility. The beds were very comfortable, and the windows well sound-proofed - we all slept great.\u2028\nAffordable - the 2 bedroom suite was not really more expensive than taking two separate rooms - but was much more fun for all.\u2028\u2028\nStaff - the Beacon staff were always helpful and efficient.\u2028\nCons:\u2028\nThe only sort-of con is that the Beacon does not have much lobby space, or a full-service concierge service. There are only 2 PCs for all guests. Breakfast is not available, but in this neighborhood you just go out the door and have many excellent options.\n\u2028\u2028All-in-all we loved our stay at the Beacon. Great views, excellent housekeeping, very clean. The bathroom was a little small but other than that the rooms were a very good size, particularly the lounge and dining areas. There was a 24 hour laundry on level 7 and for $10 in quarters, you can do two loads of washing and drying (this includes washing powder, etc). Coins can be obtained from reception. This was very handy for us as we have two young boys. There are several eateries nearby which deliver to the hotel, so even though there is no room service, you can still enjoy this option. We didn't enjoy the diner next door but the hotel staff did recommend a couple of other places nearby which were good. Across the road there are two delis/markets, with a number of others a block away also. We found Citarella much better than Fairways in terms of quality, although it does close earlier in the evening. After a long day of walking and site seeing, you can purchase a roast chicken, mash potatoes and vegetables/salads from Citarella and enjoy them in your room...a great option. Another benefit is the 1, 2, 3 subway stop just a two minute walk from the hotel, which pretty much gets you to anywhere you need to go in the city. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 4.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 4.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cThe most room for your family-vacation buck in NYC\u201d", "text": "After researching for weeks I choose the Hotel Beacon for my family's stay during our vacation in NYC. This hotel offered the most space I could find without paying for a \"suite\" . Our room consisted of two bedrooms, two bathrooms (great for families), a full kitchen and a living room. This was unbelievably priced at about $500. Cheap by no means, but any other comparable amount of space in the city would be well into $1,000s. \nThe room was kept clean and well decorated in pastel/green colors. There were nice-sized closets so bags were not laying on the floor. Big windows in each room, however we were not high enough to get a view of the city (Room 906). But a decent view of the activity on Broadway below could be seen. Each room had a flat-panel TV and there was one more TV in the living room (no fights over what to watch). Beds were comfortable with nice comforters sheets which seemed new. Having multiple bathrooms saved us plenty of time getting two kids under 10 ready for the day or ready for bed. One of the bathrooms had a tub, the other had a walk-in shower. We did have a problem with the A/C going out one night - we were there when it was 102, so that didn't score positive points with us. However it was fixed quickly and the maintenance person had a friendly attitude. In fact, all staff we came into contact with (doormen, housekeeping) had good attitudes and seemed happy to be there.\nThe location was great for families - no hassles or large crowds associated with Mid-town but not \"dead\" either. There are two markets directly across the street which we visited for food to take advantage of the kitchen. If you choose not to cook there are plenty of other restaurant options in the immediate area. Another reason I liked this hotel was there was a subway station a short block down the street which connected us to Midtown/Times Sq in minutes. \nMy biggest complaint was the daily internet cost - In this age I feel internet should be complimentary. Plus it was inconvenient to have to call to the front desk everyday for an internet code.\nOverall, I would definitely stay here again if I came to NYC with my family. {"ratings": {"cleanliness": 4.0, "sleep_quality": 4.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 4.0, "service": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cFamilies from all over the world come here\u201d", "text": "This was a great experience for us, a family of four visiting an older daughter. I'll try to provide some details that might help.\nFirst, as you probably know, the hotel is 3 blocks to Central Park and about the same distance to the Am. Museum of Nat'l HIstory. There is a subway station a block away at pretty Verdi Square at 72d & Broadway. Next to the station is a Trader Joe's and Gray's Papaya. The station serves the lines to Lincoln Center, Columbus Circle and Times Square. Broadway at this point is a divided street with a median of trees and flowerbeds. Across the street are two markets. Next door is a wine store and a cafe. On the corner is a Stabucks. \nBroadway is lined with beautiful residential buildings around the Beacon, and there is a good mix of commerce (a Barney's), markets, theaters, and restaurants. We walked Broadway from the Beacon in the uptown direction as far as 83rd (Artie's Delicatessen) and \"downtown\" to 71st (a beautiful Gothic church). We walked to Columbus Ave. (Isabella's and the museum, both at 77th) via 75th (brownstones) and to the Dakota & another subway (serving a different line to Rockefeller Center) via 72d (shops). It wasn't unusual to see a cab waiting in front of the hotel.\nFrom some descriptions I expected a small lobby and an understaffed staff. The lobby is small but very comfortable and was often used by guests to meet up with their families or to wait for a cab. Even at our very late check in, there were at least two, very friendly, very professional front desk clerks. There was no concierge, per se, but a \"customer services\" desk. Housekeeping and maintenance were equally responsive and gracious. We loved our doorman. On the day it rained, he gave us umbrellas. There are three small, quick elevators in the lobby, \nWe had a one bedroom suite. The room is done in a soft, pleasant green palette, with simple-designed furniture. Even the art is tasteful by many hotel standards. In our suite, there was a large closet at the entry, with a large flat safe that you could use with your own pin (number). The living area and the bedroom had separate, efficient climate zones.\nThe kitchenette included a sink, a microwave, an apartment refrigerator, a stove, and an electric coffee pot. We didn't ever use the stove or coffee pot. There's only a couple of pots and pans, a cutting board, some utensils, and a set of dishes, flatware, and glasses for four. I found out later that there is a little sign inside the cabinet that tells you that you can ask for more, including wine glasses and a sharp knife. Our little sinkful of dirty dishes was washed for us during the maid service. \nThere is desk near the kitchenette, another large closet in the bedroom, and lots of drawer space. Two televisions (with lots of cable choices), an ipod dock, and three phones. Ours was a very nice queen bed. The sofa bed in the living room didn't look like much but was surprisingly comfortable. \nThe bathroom is small but very pleasant. A large frosted window opens from the top, allowing air and the sounds of the city. The sill is wide enough for your personal items, as there is no vanity. The bedroom and the living room each had tall windows. The living room sill was especially wide. \nWe learned that the upper floors had good views. Our was on the 23rd floor, with views toward Central Park and over to Midtown. There were no close buildings obstructing our view. \nI first learned about this hotel from asking questions on tripadvisor, but came to learn that it is recommended by many other sources as one of the best values for families in the city. The recommendations here came from both NYC experts and people who visited from other countries. Indeed, when we were there it seemed that there were many families staying there and we heard several different languages spoken. I booked online almost 3 months in advance and got their internet special rate. If you've looked at their reservation site, you know what the rate is. My understanding from my reading is that it is the same rate year-round. I believe this is considered moderate in New York City, and I considered it a value only when I remembered (1) it was for four people, with room and (2) it was on the Upper West Side, away from (but very close to) Times Square. After making the reservation, I emailed the hotel about special requests for floor with view, late check-in, and no smoking (which I hadn't made at the time of the reservation) and I got a response within 24 hours acknowledging my requests.\nOur stay was wonderful. We relied on the subway quite a bit. We got a week's pass our first day. The trains run frequently, which is good because you get to your destination quickly and because it can get pretty hot down there waiting. 72d is a good station because all the lines it serves stop there and it is right next to the hotel. I carried a map on our outings which had the official MTA map on it. I never felt unsafe on the streets or on the subway.", "author": {"username": "bleicherblog", "num_cities": 10, "num_helpful_votes": 25, "num_reviews": 27, "location": "Albuquerque, New Mexico", "id": "648B26D8F5CB5F94D95CC5205C2FDA25"}, "date_stayed": "July 2011", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 11, "date": "August 9, 2011", "id": 116490221, "via_mobile": false}

{"ratings": {"cleanliness": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "service": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cOur best decision!!\u201d", "text": "We booked a trip to New York in order to explore, shop and see the fireworks on 4th July as well as celebrate my husband's birthday. I had travelled here twice before and always in winter and stayed very centrally. This time we wanted to be out of the centre in order to be able to stroll around easily and enjoy areas more frequented by New Yorkers. We chose the Hotel Beacon because of the area (upper west side) and reviews on Trip Advisor. We could not have been happier!! The hotel is star rated lower because there is no restaurant or bar onsite. The rooms are certainly worthy of at least a 4* rating. We had a superior room with a kingsize bed, small (but perfectly formed) kitchenette, bathroom with bath. The room also had a small seating area with coffee table and two chairs, a desk and spectacular views. The hotel staff were smart, friendly and helpful, the concierge provided us with a really useful map and there was a folder in the room with suggestions and recommendations for local restaurants and other local venues - if you travel here look in this early on - it really is useful. Our room was kept spotless and they ask how often you wish your bedding changed in order to remain as green as possible - so it really is your choice.\nLocally we found a fantastic market selling everything opposite, don't miss the wonderful cafe upstairs! There is a recommended diner/restaurant next door, but we did not try this - too many other options. Our favourite was a sushi/asian cuisine restaurant just around the block on Amsterdam Avenue, so good we ate there 3 times in 8 days! Cannot recommend any one dish as they were all superb - sit outside to get a feel for the real New York. Also further up the road don't miss 16 Handles the frozen yoghurt place - the flavours change regularly - we found it after watching literally tens of new yorkers wandering by with tubs in their hands! Also further up we feel Fred's deserves a mention great food, very friendly and again you can sit outside and watch the world go by. \nWith the advantage of a fridge in the room we did a little food (and wine) shopping so that on two occasions when we had walked our feet off and could not manage to get back, bath and redress to go out again, we curled up in the armchairs and enjoyed a light meal in our room. Wine-wise there is a fantastic off license just two doors down from the hotel, fantastic selection and lots of information about the wines. Our regret was we missed out on tickets at the Beacon Theatre - literally next door. Check out the website as this is the most convenient venue in New York for this hotel! \nOnly one small down point to mention, wifi is available but at a cost of $9.99 per day - yes there is a Starbucks two doors down but that is not much use if you are planning your day last thing at night before bed! It would be nicer if the hotel would consider a one off charge - we stayed 8 days and paid for two lots of 24 hours. The service is available so either a maximum download or no charge at all would have been preferable rather than a daily charge.\nHowever despite that small moan - We love this area and will, most definitely return. {"ratings": {"cleanliness": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "service": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cStar on Broadway\u201d", "text": "We stayed here for my partners 40th Birthday trip last December and while it wasn't my first choice of hotel I am so glad we booked it. I had looked at a lot of hotels for our trip but the high cost of rooms at this time of year narrowed our choice somewhat. The Beacon was a bargain compared to many others. Our spacious room had two double beds, a small kitchen area, spotlessly clean bathroom and a great view. We ate breakfast in the room a few times - just cereal and toast but the kitchen was more than adequate and a great way of keeping your costs down. The hotel is a block away from the subway but you can walk to Times Square etc in around 30-40 minutes. It is also just a few blocks away from Central Park which has to be one of my favourite places - great for people and dog watching. Although The Beacon doesn't have any restaurant / bar facilities there are plenty to choose from right on the doorstep. One of our favourites was http://www.goodenoughtoeat.com/ - try the strawberry butter - amazing! The Fairway market directly opposite the hotel also has a great cafe upstairs as well as a fantastic choice of foodstuffs - my partner was very impressed by the choice of cereals and pop tarts! but they also do some great deli dishes. \nNew York in December is very, very busy but beautiful - the shops / streets are wonderfully decorated and there is a great buzz about the place. There was no restaurant or on-site breakfast... but next door there was a coffee shop, two doors down there was a Starbucks, across the street was a supermarket with a \"bistro\"-style restaurant upstairs, and we were on the Upper-West Side of Manhattan, so finding food at any time was no problem. And with the kitchen, we saved a lot of money by eating in for breakfast every day and a couple of times for dinner during our week-long stay. I needn't have worried.\nThe suite we were in was very spacious (huge by NYC standards!) lovely and spotlessly clean, very comfortable indeed with a massive bed and loads of storage. There were 3 wardrobes, so I could afford to have a 'wedding dress cupboard' as well as hanging up our other clothes. 2 large TVs with a full range of cable channels including movies.\nThe kitchenette was very handy and The Fairway across the road is impressive as reported by other reviewers.\nThe upper West Side location is a leafy and pleasant area and was a relief to return to after the chaos of downtown. The Park & Natural history museum are very close and we found everything we found we needed within a few blocks - pharmacy, stationers, off licence, hairdresser, nail salon to name a few. Try Arties diner on W83rd/broadway we only found it on our last day, was filled withlocals, great food.\nThe subway is very close and easy to use - just jump on the red line! It's a 5min trip to times square and beyond goes all the way downtown to staten island ferry via Greenwich village and all in-between. Very easy trip.\nThe staff were unfailing pleasant and friendly, however we learnt to to request things (eg \nextra glasses sent up/ someone to come & fix telly) twice every time as any request made was never completed first time - although they were always very positive when request made.\nThe only other slight criticisms I'd make are that the air con in our room seemed to have a loose part which jangled making it impossible to leave on at night (the one in the other room was fine though).\nAlthough there are 2 PCs available in the lobby for Internet use, WIFI in room is $10 a day. In this day & age free wifi needs to be standard. Also it says 20mins max on a PC but there was a man who seemed to be on it all day everyday, I don't even think he was a hotel guest. I wouldn't mention it, but we desperately needed to print off an important doc asap and this man informed us he would be at least another hour - some monitoring of the Internet use would have come in handy there!\nVery minor niggles in what was overall a fantastic stay. (It's located at 2130 Broadway). So, it's very easy to get to the Times Square area from the hotel. Remember that when you are going north/south, 20 blocks equal one mile. The east/west blocks downtown are much longer - one of their blocks equal 3 north/south blocks. (this we learned on the Circle Line tour!)\nCentral Park was beauitiful - most of the blossoms were out (the magnolia trees probably bloomed completed the day after we left!). It was great having it so close to the hotel. I have stayed in Times Square before and Englewood, New Jersey. Being in the Upper West side is the best thing you can do! {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cbeacon hotel great venue for NYC\u201d", "text": "Hotel Beacon Upper West Side NYC- Dec 2010. great location.\nArrived 17.12.2010 travelled with wife and 14 year old daughter, leisure trip. Stayed for 12 nights over Xmas, so we had a good deal of time there to assess just what type of\nplace this is.\nLocation adjacent, (100 metres from 72nd st metro stop) great location, this is 4 or 5 stops from times square centre of town, ie 42nd st for all theatres etc. Metro is $2.25 per ride per person regardless of distance, so get a card which you can place $ value on and then use it all over the system. Also can be used on buses. So 3 people going all over metro system per trip is really cheap. Super convenient safe clean system.\nBut the Beacon..... clean, safe, opposite fairway, i think, super market, 24/7 place with everything and anything you can imagine, also rooms are equipped with kitchenette ie micro wave, stove, fridge & sink etc . coffee making, haridryers, full bathroom including a tub king bed in main room. We got a jnr suit for a very reasonable rate but there are the following taxes applicable to all NYC hotel stays; state tax, city tax, occupancy tax and hotel unit fee so you have to factor that in to all accommodation. Sone of the rooms on our floor, 11th overlooking Broadway, are occupied/owned by fulltime residents. So i suppose it is almost like a serviced apartment block. \nThe Beacon is worth every cent, great housekeeping, polite reception even assisted when we got hit with a Blizzard in getting us onto our airline to get out of NYC to Vegas. Free internet room off foyer, we had a couple of housekeeping malfunctions, we notified hotel and literally within 5 minutes people were at our door who actually fixed the problem. The room had movies on demand if you got sick of the 100 plus channels. 24/7 security and they are able to get you tickets to shows, tours etc if you like. \nWe cant speak highly enough of this place and would not hesitate to recommend it to\nothers, regardless of age or trip reason. The hotel is 3 or 4 blocks walk from Central Park which is itself amazing, 3 or 4 blocks from Lincoln Centre which houses opera, ballet and movies etc. You can walk to 5th Ave or just down Broadway as a tourist.\nColumbus and Amsterdam are 1 or 2 blocks East of the hotel and they are crammed with restaurants. Beacon has cafe Viand in the building, didnt try it. But the supermarket opposite has a breakfast floor which is great for brekky and reasonable if you dont want to use the kitchen.\nThe prices in Midtown are substantially more for similar quality of that offered by the Beacon we had friends there asnd saw there rooms. We stayed at the Woolcott Hotel on 34th Street for 5 nights also and though nice it was not a patch on the Beacon, more expensive BUT you could walk to 42 Street and Madison Square Garden. \nTips for Beacon use the free internet, walk to metro and use it to go both downtown and also uptown to Harlem directly. Walk to Central Park, walk to the Dakota Building where tragically John LENNON was murdered and Strawberry Fields rememberance area. Get all your groceries at the supermarket opposite Beacon which also has barb B Q chooks hot off the rotisserie for lunch, which are great for sandwiches for kids and pre packed salads very reasonably priced. Walk down to Lincoln centre and checkout movies playing if you want a quiet night in. Go out the hotel turn right heard uptown cross Broadway for 2 blocks and there is Nicks Hamburger joint which has huge menu and great burgers, pasta, fries shakes etc and all reasonable, open 24/7 dinner for 3 of us @ $40. Also chilli and peppers pizza joint in street behind hotel which is really cheap and sells pie by the slice with a nice salad, dinner for 3 of us was @ $25.\nAlso if you are looking to shop, get the metro up to Harlem. There is Marshalls store there which has heaps of sport gear like Nike, Reebok, And 1, etc etc all cheap and lots of street wear shops stocking levis etc. I priced a pair of nikeair max s in midtown and Macys then went to harlem and got the same shoes for $50 USD less!!!!!!! Also at Macys take your passport in and get a discount card for 10% on all purchases. There are lots of branded clothes and shoes discounted throughout NYC, (according to my 14 year old daughter and lots of nice boutiques in Amsterdam and Columbus near Beacon), also a great flea market on Sunday on West 78 St (I think), which has great jewellery and furs etc, also vintage clothes.\nIn our opinion if you are visiting NYC and you want safe,clean,friendly and competitively priced accommodation you cant go past the Beacon Hotel.", "author": {"username": "clariceSydney", "num_cities": 5, "num_helpful_votes": 9, "num_reviews": 5, "num_type_reviews": 5, "id": "FBC04A7DCD0DB55A3A07F50C8017EF33", "location": "sydney"}, "date_stayed": "December 2010", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 5, "date": "January 3, 2011", "id": 91483967, "via_mobile": false}

{"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cGreat Hotel, Great Value, Great Location...\u201d", "text": "I can't say enough good things about Hotel Beacon. This hotel was recommended by a friend of my sister's and it lived up to its reputation. It reminded me of a small, boutique type of hotel with more personalized service. The Beacon is located on the upper west side, a perfect location...still close to all the action, but you feel like you are in a more residential area than the hustle and bustle of being downtown. Somehow, it reminded me of Europe.\nI was in NYC to watch my niece graduate from college and so my husband and I, plus my sisters, mother and extended family all stayed at Hotel Beacon. We had a king room and my other family members had a king suites. The rooms were spacious and very clean. We had a small kitchenette which we really didn't use, but it was great to have just in case. We stayed for 5 nights and it was so comfortable that I felt like I was living there. The king suites were also very nice and spacious. The only suggestion I would make for fellow women travelers is to bring your own hair dryer because the ones that are in the rooms are the standard dryers that attached to the wall. \nThe location of the hotel was perfect! It is a block away from the subway, close to shopping and wonderful restaurants, and within walking distance to the American Museum of Natural History. There is a great wine shop next door that had a huge selection. Across the street is Fairway's Market and Citarella that had everything you could want...great selection of cheeses, salamis, desserts, food, etc. A few blocks up the street is the well known Zabar's which, in my opinion, if you are a food lover you must check it out. Also, next door to the hotel is Viand Cafe that had a variety of home cooked choices. Can't forget to mention that there is a Starbuck's on the corner! On arrival after getting up at 2:30am in Aneheim to fly across, we were greeted by friendly porters and reception staff who quickly sorted out our luggage and keys. It was the 4th of July and so a very busy tourist day for Manhattan. The consierge kindly told us the quickest and best way to get to the Hudson River so we could see the fireworks and it was only a 10 min walk. We were impressed by the quality and size of our 2 bedroom apartment style rooms given the price. They managed to squeeze in 2 bathrooms which is a godsend with a family of 6. The Kitchenette had a fridge, oven and stovetop, another great plus for families.. The hotel has no restaurant but really this should not put you off as right next door is a great, economical diner that has been around forever and you can get a great breakfast, lunch or dinner there. There is also a Starbucks next to that so coffee is sorted. Even better was across the road there are 2 supermarkets, one is an upmarket gourmet foodies heaven with loads of pre made food, seafood, bakery items, cakes, pastas etc. The other is called Food World and has EVERYTHING you could possible want. We got breakfast items there like cereal and bagels. The apartment had a mini kitchen which meant we could save a little and eat in a bit more, after the family junk restaurants of Aneheim we craved fresh food. The hotel is a 2min walk to 72nd st subway station and 2 blocks to central park, if you walk down 72nd st you get to the part of the park where the John Lennon imagine memorial is. If you then head across and up you are hitting Park Ave before you know it and will have seen most of the major sites of the park on the way. \nAt night we would usually eat in Times Square, you must if you have teenagers take them to The Hard Rock Cafe, it has the best memorablilia and got our kids excited. Another top spot is the Bubba Gump Shrimp Co restaurant from the Forest Gump movie. My husband and I found a romantic Italian restaurant around the corner and managed a night out ALONE. \nI have no complaints about the hotel, we will stay there again and next time for longer, it was nice to be a little removed from the 24 hr feel of Time Square and near all the Sesame Street like houses that we all imagine when thinking of NYC. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cKnocks spots off the Waldorf\u201d", "text": "We just visited NYC for the second time for my husbands 40th and stayed at the Beacon. \nIt is absolutely fantastic and like others have said, makes you feel like you are living in New York.\nIf you like people fussing over you, paying over the odds for room service and a posh lobby with hotel bar, this is not the place for you. If, however, you want great friendly and efficient service, and a large comfortable room in a great area of the city, the Beacon is for you.\nWe had a 1 bed king suite and it was huge. The bathroom was marble lined and spotlessly clean. Not huge but easily comparable to the average home bathoom in England. Lovely Gilchrist and Soames toiletries as well.\nThe king bed was lovely and comfortable and we could actually lay in bed and see the New York sky line ........amazing.\nThe living room with kitchen was fantastic. Although we didn't cook, we did use the coffee maker and free coffee. On my husbands birthday I went next door to the Viand cafe and got a breakfast takeout to eat in the room. We had everything 'american' that I could think to order. It was fantastic and a snip at $20 compared to the $98 we paid for room service at the Waldorf last time we came to New York.\nThe fridge is full size with a freezer compartment so you can easily go to the Fairway market to fill up on essentials if you want.\nThe area is amazing. Really pretty with tons of great restaurants and bars. The area feels totally safe to walk around even at night. I could give you a list of places to go but I think half the fun is finding them for yourself.\nThe hotel is really close to central park which is an absoulute delight. We just sat watching people for hours. I kept waiting for Woody Allen to appear from behind a tree as we encountered so many characters.\nI would personally not bother to stay anywhere else in New York now. Although the Waldorf was great last time, the suite at the Beacon was just as big and actually more comfortable. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cExcellent location, friendly staff and good sized room\u201d", "text": "We stayed here due to the continually great reviews on Trip Advisor and we weren't disappointed. We arrived earlier than normal for check-in but got a room on the 15th floor immediately. The room was clean and fresh - one good-sized bed, bathroom and kitchenette. Our room faced north so the views weren't exactly spectacular if that's something you really want from your experience! Air conditioning worked like a charm and the black-out blind was superb. The only noise experienced was from the a/c machine itself but that's to be expected isn't it? Our room also contained a safe - great for leaving passports and extra cash at the hotel.\nThe bathroom was again a good size especially considering it is a hotel in NYC - the shower pressure was very powerful and the bathroom was immaculately clean (I'm a clean freak!). As other reviewers have said before, the kitchenette is very handy. We did what everyone else seems to do and bought stuff for breakfast and sometimes lunches from the Fairway market directly across the road. The kitchenette had the basics for in-room eating, along with tea and coffee making facilities. There was a list of additional items available from reception if needed but we managed fine! The fridge didn't seal closed properly but we just set it to the coldest temperature possible and it worked like a treat! \nThe staff were very friendly especially the guys working at the front door. They are a credit to the hotel and suggested places to eat which were appropriate for our needs. (We discovered our new favourite restaurant because of them - thanks!). Big Nicks burgers were awesome, Cafe Viand was nice - big portions of caesar salad which we had boxed up to go because we couldn't finish, Levains bakery had the best warm chocolate chip cookies I have EVER tasted and Gray's Papaya was good for a quick, light and cheap hotdog fix on the way home after a day/evening out. \nFree internet access was available in a small room with 2 computers just off the lobby. Again, as other reviewers have mentioned, it was very very slow! We ended up asking the concierge to print off our boarding passes from his computer which he did without any fuss. The laundry facilities on the 7th floor are brilliant. I think I was $1.25 for a small box of washing powder which would have done 2 washes then about $1.75 for use of the machine (don't quote me on the prices but I reckon they're close enough!). There were numerous washing machines and driers, along with a bench and vending machine if you're planning to wait. \nThe subway was a couple of minutes walk south and had great connections. We also used the bus to go across town and back up to the hotel from the bottom of Central Park - easy to navigate once you check out the maps at the bus stop otherwise they can appear a bit daunting! We bought a $27 unlimited 9-day metro card each from the subway station which was a great deal and also let us use the buses.\nMy photographs all show the inside of a suite on the 11th floor (we upgraded for our last night as a treat) and the view is also from this room. However, the bedroom is not dissimilar from a standard room (standard also had a work desk) but the bathroom in the suite appeared to be smaller than the standard. It was great having a separate livingroom in the suite but we had no problems staying in the standard room and would do so again!\nAll in all, a great hotel with lovely staff, plenty of space and basic amenities along with many great resaturants nearby!", "author": {"username": "Jillish2311", "num_cities": 10, "num_helpful_votes": 9, "num_reviews": 10, "num_type_reviews": 8, "id": "18FD9306918C94EB18AC1515EE3229A5", "location": "Dundee"}, "date_stayed": "September 2010", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 2, "date": "October 4, 2010", "id": 82101293, "via_mobile": false}

{"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cWonderfully located, friendly, good value and huge rooms!\u201d", "text": "The hotel was very easy to reach from JFK. We got the airport transfer train to Jamaica station and then the overland train to Penn station then the subway to 72nd street. The whole thing took about 50 minutes and seemed to be the cheapest option. There is plenty of signposting and it really is simple. From 72nd street subway station you can almost see the hotel, takes about three minutes walk. \nUpon arrival we were greeted by friendly smiley staff and were checked in quickly and efficiently. The room we had was lovely and was on the 14th floor, was great value for money and very roomy. It was newly decorated and had great views. There were two double beds in the room, lots of storage, a free safe very handy. The room also had a kitchen and table area which was again very useful. The fridge is a good size and there was also a hob and a microwave. We didnt eat in but you could have done easily. We also requested champagne glasses one evening and the staff brought some up to us. There is the fairway market accross the street and a nice wine shop a few doors down for stores. The room was very modern, had a light and airy feel and had effective air con. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 4.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 5.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cNear Perfect Stay...Would recommend\u201d", "text": "My husband, my 9 year old daughter, and I stayed here over Labor Day weekend to attend the US Open. We stayed in a large King Suite, with kitchenette and sofa bed. The room appeared to be recently renovated, and is tasteful decorated. The king size bed was extremely comfortable, and the quality of the bedding was great. Our room (#919) was perfectly quiet, since it was not facing the street, and was the last room on the hall. While it had no view (other than rooftops), I would give up a view anyday for quiet. The kitchen (with oven/stove/microwave/refrig) was an added \"plus\".The only reason for four stars instead of five: the AC in the living room was not working properly. We reported this on Sat., and as of today, had not been repaired. Fortunately, the milder temps, and the powerful bedroom AC, made the situation bearable. The front desk reduced our bill appropriately as a gesture of \"service recovery.\" The number of TV channels was infinite, and we especially appreciated having The Tennis Channel, since we were there to attend the US Open. The location is just a few short blocks from the 73 Ave. train station, which made moving throughout the city very easy . It is a short 30 minute taxi ride from LGA (appox. $35). Central Park is within walking distance. \nOther reviewers have mentioned the market across the street...but I would be remiss if I failed to comment that it was exceptionally convenient. We ate several meals in our room, thanks to the fully cooked meals that were available in this \"super-duper market\". No breakfast is offered at this hotel, but you don't need it...get breakfast from the market, or get it from the restaurant on the corner. \nThe front desk staff were very helpful, especially the Bell Hops. They offered detailed instructions on navigating the subway system. The front desk offers round-trip subway passes for purchase ($4.50), and they were always ready to get a taxi for us. \nThe restaurant on the corner (adjacent to the hotel) offers excellent menu selection, and huge portions. The pasta meals can easily serve two. \nThe housekeeping staff was very good. We had a one bedroom suite with 2 queen beds and a pullout sofa in living room. The suite was decorated very tastefully. I had to make a last minute quick trip to NYC and all of my usual choices were booked. I was surprised because it was mid-week, but apparently there were a number of graduations and everyone was fully booked. I stumbled across Hotel Beacon and got what I believe was the last room. I paid more than I would for pleasure travel, but again given that it was my only choice I am not complaining. I believe the average rates are actually less than what I paid so I think the average value is fine. It was a suite with two double beds (more than I needed, but may be great on a future trip). I was quite surprised at the size as well. I am certain this suite was much larger than many Manahattan apartments. The bathroom was quite large for an NYC boutique. Though I did not need it, I loved having the option of the kitchenette. My room windows did not face the street, but were very new commercial quality and it was the quietest night I've ever spent in NYC. My only complaint (which I expressed in the form of a suggestion to the front desk) was to upgrade the shower head (it was adequate, but the standard type from the hardware store). I feel like they paid alot of attention to detail on every mater, but to compete fully in the boutique market the shower needs to feel invigorating. It is in the Upper West Side, away from the hustle and bustle of downtown and Times Square. This was appealing to us, as there is so much to see on the way downtown. Taxis are cheap compared to Australia so for us, a $10 cab ride to Times Square was great. I would recommend walking through most of the city though, as there is so much to see and do along the way! Just a note - as a young female traveller - I felt very comfortable walking the streets surrounding the hotel by myself. The city is much cleaner and safer than I ever expected!\nThe rooms were fantastic! Recently renovated, with a funky green throughout. The 1 bedroom apartments are huge, with either 1 king or 2 doubles in a separate bedroom plus kitchen facilities and a lounge room. Bathrooms are on the small side, but there is so much space elsewhere it is not a drama. \nThe lobby is quite small, but this is also what we found to be appealing. The lobby is nondescript. There is no restaurant (save the greasy-spoon next door). \nThe rooms ARE spacious (indeed gigantic for New York) and the amenities nice. The decor is rather dated (circa 2001), so it already feels like it's time for a remodel. The bathroom is ridiculously small -- sink, toilet, tub/shower literally touching each other. Be warned, if you get a room on one of the lower floors (where they first tried to place us) your view will likely be a brick wall with no to little natural light.\nThe service was almost non-existent. Also the hairdryer in the bathroom was woeful - remember to take your own! Otherwise a perfect stay. Our living room sofa was a ready dressed sofa bed which enabled a friend to stay over a couple of times during the week and the double glazing was amazing and blocked out all noise from the streets below - but there is air con. Their website states \"Wireless Internet in all rooms\" - this is certainly true but for a day rate of $9.95 per day - you need to activate it for each day you want it and it's pretty slow. The hotel doesn't have a restaurant or offer room service but there are plenty of bars/restaurants close by and various markets/grocery shops opposite the hotel where you can get snacks/meals/alcohol...also plenty of takeaways deliver to your hotel room. My husband & I stayed at this hotel about 7 years ago, and the hotel has been significantly upgraded during this time. We were assigned a room on the 9th floor, located next to the elevators. The room was spacious for 2 adults - two closets (one with a safe), a living area with a 3-seater sofa which may have had a pullout bed (I didn't check); 2 flat screen TV's - one on the bedroom, one in the living area; a cozy kitchenette with fridge, stove, oven, etc; a queen-sized bed; some drawer space; and a small but usable bathroom - the water pressure was average but heated up quickly and stayed warm throughout the shower. A door seperated the living area from the bedroom for added privacy. There is a significant number of channels available on the TV so finding something to watch shouldn't be difficult. The room had 2 large windows overlooking the NYC cityscape. Adorable artwork lining the walls provided a more comfortable \"home\" feel rather than just a hotel room. Wi-Fi was provided for a \"nominal fee\" and you had to get a code from the reception desk - we never used this service so I'm unable to comment. The only downsides were since our room was so close to the elevator, we heard the pullies and the opening/closing of the doors all night; the carpet was a bit frayed in corners. Also, the heater in our room was noisy and turned on and off all night, which could possibly disturb someone who is a light sleeper. The deskman provided a good recommendation for a nearby restaurant, and the meal was delicious. Across the street is a market and the subway is about a block or two away. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "location": 4.0, "sleep_quality": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cClean, comfortable, spacious, well equipped.\u201d", "text": "Reasonably priced big city hotels tend to be a little cramped. This Hotel isn't. The room we stayed in last week was more than adequate. It contained 2 large comfortable beds,\nan easy chair with a foot rest, a dining table with 2 chairs. A desk with an office chair. Plenty of clothing storage space. Additionally the Environment was well controlled by a quiet Aircon/ Heater Unit. A well provisioned Kitchenette area with fridge, microwave, hob unit and toaster with sufficient utensils for the two of us.\nThe 32\" TV had more channels than we cared to watch. A nice touch was the Iphone docking station. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0, "location": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cA comfortable hotel in a quiet but well located area\u201d", "text": "This hotel is located in upper mid west Manhatten. If you are the type of person who thrives on bright lights, the hustle of the town centre don't come here. The hotel is two very small blocks from the 72 street subway, turn left out of the hotel. It took no time at all to get to where ever we wanted on the Island. Fairway supermarket is over the road but if you cross over, then turn right there is another smaller super market on the next block which is not so crowded. However, we really liked Wholefoods - get off the Metro at Columbus circle and head for the shopping centre, the supermarket is downstairs. It has loads of fresh, semi prepared meals or buffet type offerings but the system for lining up at the tills is really odd and I fell foul of it, tut tut. \nAnyway, back to the hotel. We stayed in a one bedroom suite on the 12th floor with a view out the front. We had a bedroom with TV, storage was excellent. The lounge had a chair and sofa, big TV, round dining table, a work table (for computer with lamp) and kitchenette. The kitchenette had a toaster, fridge/freezer, gas cooker, whistling kettle, coffee maker, one saucepan, frying pan, cutlery and plates. They do supply tea towels and some washing up liquid was left. The bathroom was small but perfectly fine. A free copy of USA today was left outside the door weekdays. An ironing board and safe was located in the hallway. It was hot air central heating but it did not affect my asthma. This broke down one evening and an engineer came right up to fix it at 10 in the night which I thought excellent. If you want newspapers, there is a newstand over the road. Starbucks is located to the right, just over the road which is useful if you have just arrived and are starving. We went to the little restaurant on the right of the hotel as you go out which was nice but once you add in service charge, tips etc, we thought it was getting too pricey to return. There are lots of small little places to eat around here which would cover every foodie interest. We appreciated being able to cook for ourselves as it did save a few bucks plus by the time we got home in early evening we were too tired to contemplate going out again!\nCheck in was excellent. We had to sign a declaration promising not to smoke in a non-smoking room and leave credit card details which were used to pay for wi fi of 9.95 dollars a day, the connection was excellent. If you are wondering about how to print out an electronic boarding pass, go down to the lobby; to the left of the lifts is a small cubby hole with two computers and two printers. The printers were down the night we wanted them but the chap on duty suggested we email our pdf to him and he kindly printed it out for us. There is a fitness centre that guests can use (not sure where it is) but is was 20 dollars a day.\nSome general tips. Get a metro card for the appropriate number of days, excellent value and good service. Go early in the morning to the popular locations such as Empire State Building and the ferry over to Liberty Island as it can get crazy. Central park is within strolling distance. We left a tip each day for the room attendant. Street parking around there looked fine though you'd need to go around the blocks a few times and hope to get lucky. Easy to get a taxi, just ask the DoorMan and the fares were very reasonable, the metro is not so good crossing east west so this was a good option.\nOverall, an excellent experience and I can't compliment the staff enough.", "author": {"username": "21Summer", "num_cities": 22, "num_helpful_votes": 41, "num_reviews": 38, "num_type_reviews": 29, "id": "A9D1F22BC416E73F3414BA8CB9F2E234", "location": "Wales"}, "date_stayed": "January 2010", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 2, "date": "January 10, 2010", "id": 53124987, "via_mobile": false}

{"ratings": {"service": 4.0, "cleanliness": 4.0, "overall": 4.0, "value": 4.0, "rooms": 4.0, "location": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cSolid choice in city of endless choices\u201d", "text": "Being very familiar with NYC and traveling there often; the Beacon is a very good choice for a short or extended stay. The location is excellent on the Upper Westside close enough to midtown for tourists/business but far enough away to enjoy a neighborhood feel. Endless choices for restaurants between Columbus, Broadway and Amsterdam; good shopping choices, close to Central Park and all the excellent museums/Lincoln Center/Greenmarkets/Columbus Circle etc. Transporation is close with 1-2-3 lines within two short blocks and A & C two long blocks away. Area is very safe. Starbucks right next door, local diners for decent breakfast, Crumbs cupcakes within a block, Fairway across the street to stock up if you are the room cooking type - what more do you need?\nThe hotel itself provides kitchenettes with every room configuration from doubles, to king to suites. {"ratings": {"service": 4.0, "cleanliness": 4.0, "overall": 4.0, "value": 5.0, "rooms": 4.0, "location": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cGood Hotel, Good Price, Good Neighborhood\u201d", "text": "My family has stayed at the Beacon many times since we discovered it 15 years ago. It's in a very nice neighborhood (Broadway and 74th). There's a subway stop almost at the door, and dozens of good restaurants and shops within walking distance. The staff is consistently outstanding. The hotel sometimes shows its age with a little wear and tear in the rooms. But, it's always clean and never less than acceptable. The prices have crept up over the years, but it's still a good deal. We almost always get a 1-bedroom suite, and it's usually less than $250. Unless you insist on the top of the line elegance, you can't go wrong with this place. A cost cutting tip for out of town travelers with a car: There is plenty of safe, free residential neighborhood parking within a few blocks of the hotel, so you don\u2019t have to pay for a garage. Just cruise the neighborhoods from about 71st to 78th between Central Park West and Riverside and watch the signs for No Parking days. {"ratings": {"service": 4.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 4.0, "value": 5.0, "rooms": 3.0, "location": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cComfortable, but not as pictured\u201d", "text": "We spent seven nights at this hotel with our granddaughter. Check-in was prompt and courteous and we were on our way to our room within minutes. Unfortunately, we were disappointed in the size of the area where the sofa bed was located, with its adjoining tiny kitchenette (once the sofa bed was opened, you could not get to the window). As to the sofa bed comfort, it was most uncomfortable for our granddaughter, but on the following morning, upon leaving for the day, when the manager was notified, an additional mattress pad was placed on the bed and it increased her comfort considerably. There are more closets than rooms. Each one is enormous, with lots of hangers. The bathroom is very small, with minimal shelf space and no exhaust fan, thus, it became very steamy after showering. On the plus side, the shower pressure was outstanding. The towels were thick and fluffy, but we had to ask each day for additional towels, or helped ourselves to some from the cart. There was some noise from adjoining rooms, but this was not a major issue. Overall, the staff could not have been nicer. The location of the hotel is terrific - near a subway and buses.\nThe Fairway Market, across the street, is as advertised. If they don't have it, it doesn't exist. As a matter of fact, we had dinner twice in their upstairs restaurant - service and food is excellent.\nLet us say a word, as other posters have indicated, about the restaurant mentioned several times, \"La Vela\", 373 Amsterdam Ave (at 75th or 76th St.). We dined there twice. The food is not pretentious but is terrific, the service is excellent and the wines reasonable priced, as is the food.\nWe also ate at Fusha, just around the corner from the hotel on Amsterdam Ave (at 75th St.). It is Asian fusion, not inexpensive, but excellent, and again, the staff is very good and friendly.\nWe recommend getting a Metro Pass for the time you are in the city. The desk at the hotel has daily passes, but if you are there longer, you can purchase longer passes at the subway stations. The subways and buses are air-conditioned and surprisingly clean and run often. We never took a taxi.", "author": {"username": "lightpackers", "num_cities": 22, "num_helpful_votes": 17, "num_reviews": 22, "num_type_reviews": 21, "id": "F11A1AD6A07BEDBAA78A52F4901FB33F", "location": "tucson"}, "date_stayed": "August 2009", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 3, "date": "August 12, 2009", "id": 37513038, "via_mobile": false}
