Over the road is Fairways deli-supermarket, with a huge selection of fresh fruit and vegies, hot meals, Bar B Q chooks, pastries, pies, quiches, gourmet shelf lines and deli items. The Beacon bottle shop is excellent, and I found several preservative free wines, which is more then I can at home in Sydney. There is free internet access in a little room off the lobby, which is always a plus with me.\nAs it was my first visit to New York, I was a bit concerned, as I had heard people could be rude or abrupt, but I did not encounter this anywhere. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "rooms": 5.0, "location": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cThe Beacon shines brightly!\u201d", "text": "What a pleasure! The freshly renovated, attractive & comfortably furnished accommodations really do look like the photos on the hotel's website, but the photos do not show just how airy and spacious the bedroom of our suite was, the size of the walk-in closet (with window), how well-equipped the compact kitchen is (toaster, microwave, basic cookware, small range with oven, microwave, sink & refrigerator). The bathroom, however, is quite compact, and the towels are not luxuriously thick.\nIn addition to the closet space, there were ample drawers for the 3 of us; the large flat-screen TV was directly across from the sofa; excellent climate control, an ergonomic desk chair; and the iPod docking station was a nice touch -- all features, I might add, that were not to be found in the Sofitel suite in which I stayed 2 weeks later at twice the price. And, my friend reported that the sofabed was surprisingly comfortable. \nThis is not a deluxe hotel with full-service amenities, such as a bar & restaurant. But the immediate environs offer a variety of those & food markets; a gym [day passes available to hotel guests at a discount] and a good wine shop are just next door; and the neighborhood, one of my favorites, delighted my out-of-town friends as much as I hoped. For those staying longer, there are also coin-operated washers & dryers in a pleasant-enough laundry room on the 7th floor. Lastly, the staff was unfailingly pleasant, welcoming and professional. \nIf I could afford it, I'd be tempted to give up my apartment to live at the Beacon year-round; I'm sure you too will be pleased with your stay here.", "author": {"username": "CockleCove", "num_cities": 10, "num_helpful_votes": 81, "num_reviews": 22, "num_type_reviews": 14, "id": "F31683DF20AE1DB9C6094E6FCDDDE6AD", "location": "New York City, New York"}, "date_stayed": "January 2009", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 6, "date": "March 4, 2009", "id": 25553351, "via_mobile": false}

{"ratings": {"overall": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cLocation can't be beat!\u201d", "text": "I stayed two nights at the Beacon on a recent business trip. I would definitely recommend the hotel to those who are looking for a reasonably-priced hotel in a terrific location. On previous trips to the city, I'd always stayed near Rockefeller Plaza and hated the hotels there. The Beacon is a terrific alternative. It's a short walking distance from Central Park (about 5 minutes by foot to the Dakota) and conveniently located for bus or metro travel. The room is cheaply but tastefully furnished and the full kitchenette was a plus for me as I took advantage of all the epicurean markets along Broadway (definitely check out Zabars!) and had a marvellous breakfast in my room. The only downside, especially for business travelers, is that there is a $9.95 charge for wireless in the room. I remedied this by using the \"business center\" (a small, overheated, and claustrophobic room right off the lobby) that had free computer access and printing. The front desk staff and concierge staff were friendly and helpful. {"ratings": {"service": 4.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "rooms": 4.0, "location": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cSimply Brilliant\u201d", "text": "I travelled to NYC for the first time in June with a friend to celebrate our birthdays. We stayed for 10 nights at the Hotel Beacon and it was simply brilliant. The rooms have recently been refurbished and are lovely in an understated way, very clean, relatively spacious and have a well equipped kitchenette - we had breakfast most mornings in our room. The beds are very comfy. Our room was very quiet and had a magnificent view (the hotel had kindly put us on the 22nd floor given the nature of our visit and its duration). Housekeeping were very attentive and only too happy to bring anything additional you needed and in a very timely fashion. The bathroom is very small but was adequate for our needs and again very clean. Only gripe with the room was the aircon - didn't seem to very efficient as it cut out regularly and was quite noisy - this did interfere with sleeping on a couple of evenings. Hotel also has free internet for guests which we really appreciated as we were able to converse regularly with our hubbys and kids via email.\nThe hotel's location is fantastic - much quieter than midtown because you're some distance from Times Square (this was one of the reasons we chose this hotel!), Short walk to Central Park and absolutely brimming with restaurants, diners, cafes, bars, grocery stores frequented by locals, not just tourists. All the major attractions are easily accessible via the subway which is very close by, taxi or walking (we walked to Times Square regularly - took about 25min). \nMy only gripe with the hotel, and its only a small one, was with the front desk staff. With the exception of the gentleman who checked us in who was polite and provided us lots of useful info, the remaining staff were certainly not friendly and not very helpful when you needed assistance or information. A smile goes a long way guys.... We also found the night concierge to be too pushy in terms of trying to sell tickets, tours etc.. At times we were followed to the lift!! We booked everything we did directly with the tour operators, bus company, theatres etc.. easily and for a lot less than what was being offered at the hotel (assume the markup was commission but it was hefty!).\nGenerally speaking though this hotel was brilliant for the price, very good value and in a superb location. I had a one bedroom king suite; my wife joined me for the last three days.\nI was pleased upon entering the room to see that it was obviously newly-renovated. It was much nicer than the pictures on either the hotel's own website or the traveler photos here. The new rooms are in a kind of Art Deco style with earth tones predominating, and have (in the suites) two large flat-screen TVs.\nThe suites are quite spacious and it was very pleasant to stay here for such a long time. The kitchenette (sink, fridge, oven and range, microwave) meant we could eat breakfast, snacks, and some meals in the room. There was a full service for four as well as pots, pans, some cutlery and a toaster -- none of which we actually used.\nWi-Fi worked well though it was annoying to pay $9.95 a day for it as well as have to call down to the front desk every day to get a new access code.\nThe neighborhood is great, not nearly as crowded or frantic as midtown but with plenty of shopping, restaurants, and the amazing Fairway Market right across the street.\nThere were some minor staff lapses, some just annoying, one a little bit more so.\n1.) One day I was expecting both a Fed Ex and UPS delivery so upon returning in the evening stopped at the front desk to see if they had arrived, in order to save myself the trip back down from the 21st floor to pick them up. The front desk said they had arrived and to pick them up from the concierge. The concierge went back to check, said they didn't have them and sent me back to the front desk. Frustrated, I went up to the room, only to find that both packages had been left in the room already. Great service, but why couldn't the concierge have known that the packages had already been brought to the room? On another day, I got another Fed Ex and this time, the concierge left a voice mail for me to come get it. A little consistency would be nice.\n2.) When I checked in, I was surprised that they didn't swipe a credit card for incidentals (the room was a direct bill to someone else.) A couple of days later I sent some dry cleaning with the valet, and when I got back, there was a voice mail to come down to the front desk and leave a credit card imprint before they would release my suit and shirts.\n3.) Finally, the first few days the room was fairly warm and I noticed the air conditioner in the living room wasn't cooling. I asked at the front desk for someone to come fix it and no one came. The next day someone came, took the lid off, pressed a button and pronounced it fixed, but it wasn't. Finally when I insisted the next day, someone else came and actually looked at the guts of the air conditioner to discover the compressor wasn't actually working. There is a theater right next door also called the Beacon but it is seriously in need of rennovation and is not open. \nAll of the rooms have a tiny little kitchen with a smaller size refrigerator, a tiny stove with an oven, a microwave and a little sink. There is a toaster too along with dishes, a couple of cooking pans and silverware. Big Nick's Pizza and Burgers is up the street a block or two. Good pizza, didn't try the burgers.\nThe neighborhood is pleasant and we never felt unsafe walking in the area. The building is 25 stories and our room was on the 23rd floor. We paid about $380/night for this room. I thought it was a bargain considering the prices near Times Square, the size of the room and the fact that there was a kitchen. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 4.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 4.0, "location": 4.0, "sleep_quality": 4.0, "rooms": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cGreat Place\u201d", "text": "Our family just left the lovely Beacon Hotel, and we did love it. The area seems to be a mixture of visitors and upscale New Yorkers walking little dogs. I personally really preferred this area, away from the concrete jungle mid-town. The Beacon is across from two large markets, and we found the kitchen was an excellent option to break up restaurant life. The only minor complaint I may have is the Kitchen is poorly equipped, as usual if you want to cook anything bring a kitchen knife in your checked bag. Likewise, a big bowl of some sort to make sald would have been very handy. The coffee maker in the kitchen uses those little Keruig (?) cuplets which are kindly supplied at the hotel, so that was handy and delicious in the morning. Given the many comments on trip advisor about NYC generally, I must say the suite we were in at the Beacon was a generous size. It was spotlessly clean, and the view from the upper floors was fantastic. I did note one somewhat unhappy couple changing their room one morning, so perhaps the lower floor rooms are not as great. If you want to get something reasonable for dinner one night, try walking up a couple of blocks to Zabors and getting the pre-made spag and meatballs. The cheese selection was also out of this world. We really enjoyed being able to have the odd meal in our suite, and did not feel hard done by, simply, because there was such tasty take away and the room was lovely. I guess it goes without saying, that feeding a mittful of children in NYC can be a tad pricey in the restaurant scene. The staff at the Beacon were polite and kind across the board, not a bump anywhere. Also, the Beacon is a short walk to both Central and Riverside parks, both great places to walk and or jog if you are so inclined. NYC is such an amazing spot to see and experience, the Beacon was certainly not a bargain, but we did feel it was worth it's weight in gold. King size beds and tastfully furnished and even a little kitchen, which we did not use, you can eat everywhere, but the refrigerator is nice for a cold drink.\nThe neighbourhood is really nice, you stay among the residents and it is nice to see how the New Yorkers live in their really great appartments. \nWhen we arrived with the Super Shuttle (was not as bad as I read in the reviews) I was afraid the hotel was too far from everything (in 2000 I stayed in hotel Edison en Milford Plaza), but no, the metro is very nearby, and even walking was not a crime because there are shops everywhere. The staff is friendly but not over the top, (Americans are really excessive polite, we are not used to that in Holland. We think just being polite is enough) and the concierges are very helpfull.\nMidtown is the part of New York we liked fewest, very crowded. {"ratings": {"service": 4.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 4.0, "rooms": 4.0, "check_in_front_desk": 4.0, "location": 3.0}, "title": "\u201cGreat Hotel - Would recommend it for everyone\u201d", "text": "I took my parents to NY to celebrate 50 years of marriage so naturally only wanted the best for them. We booked the hotel through our travel agent, after reading previous reviews first.\nThe Hotel is in a very secure part of Manhatten. I was a little concerned initially about the location as on three previous visits i have stayed South of Columbus Circus, usually at hotels between 33rd and 50th. I thought I might have selected a hotel a little too far away from the main tourist attractions. However the transportation network is excellent. We were at Rockerfeller Centre within 20 minutes of stepping on the train at 72nd and Broadway....including walking time.\nWe arrived at the hotel at about 2pm and alas our room was not ready. So we had to sit in the lobby and wait for 40 minutes. After a long flight that was a bit disappointing. However everything was uphill from there.\nMy parents and i shared an room with excellent facilities, including kitchenette, living area, two televisions and a host of facilities we didn't actually get to use. Our room was facing broadway and i have to say that it was extremely quiet for the most part. There was, at times, some traffic noise, but to be honest, it was not too intrusive and did not affect our enjoyment of the holiday.\nThe room has a safe which is almost idiot proof and secure. Our most valuable items - including passports, insurance documents etc - were placed there.\nThe beds were perhaps a tad small for double beds. It was great for me of course as I had one to myself. I think my parents could have done with a little more room.\nThe room service was excellent. You are given the option of having your towels and bed linen changed every day, or to have them changed less frequently. This, I believe, is a concession to the more environmentally aware visitors.\nOpposite the hotel is a small market, ideally placed for visitors that want to do their own cooking. However there is a restaurant next to the hotel which serves excellent breakfast, lunch and evening meals. We used the market - after the first few days of finding our feet - to purchase our breakfast - cereal, milk and bagels. This was a lot cheaper than buying breakfast and is heartily recommended. \nThe subway is three blocks away on 72nd and Broadway. From there the whole of the main tourist spots were accessible. My advice is to get a metrocard which will allow you to travel on bus and train alike.\nIt should be noted that the front of the hotel had scaffolding due to some rennovation work on certain floors that was over-running. However we were not inconvenienced or affected by this work.\nThe staff were friendly but not in our faces...None of this sometimes false 'have a nice day' stuff, but still good at anticipating needs. My advice is to use the concierge to flag down taxis and to provide advice about tourist haunts. We were too reticent to do this - it's a British thing alas - and missed out on some useful service and advice given to others. You can grab a subway map from the concierge desk. This is helpful..\nThe hotel does arrange transportation to the airport(s). However the cost is a tad expensive when conpared with some other companies. If we go again we'll make our own arrangements and save some bucks! The service provided though by the airport bus arranged could not be faulted.\nThe hotel was frequented by a lot of Europeans. We heard German, French, Italian, Spanish and I believe Polish spoken there. There were even a couple of Australians. So it has a mixture of people. \nIn short, I would have no hesitation in recommending this hotel to all and sundry.", "author": {"username": "triptriptrip", "num_cities": 2, "num_helpful_votes": 5, "num_reviews": 2, "location": "uk", "id": "21C28370D7FB2E5E21CEBA464DB72135"}, "date_stayed": "September 2008", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 1, "date": "September 27, 2008", "id": 20416223, "via_mobile": false}

Spacious, clean & comfortable room. Very good value for money.\u201d", "text": "The Beacon is on the Upper West side of Central Park. It is on Broadway and is less than 10 minutes walk into Central Park using the W 72nd Street entrance.\nThe location is great. It is a relaxed, friendly and safe part of Manhattan. You are away from the hustle and bustle of midtown, yet it is only a 5 minute subway ride into midtown or a little longer downtown. There is a major subway station at 72nd Street (2 minutes walk away) that goes anywhere you want.\nThere is a very good supermarket (Fairway) straight across the road if you need anything. There are quite a few restaurants and cafes around the area (there is a 24 hour cafe right next door). Some are cheap and the food is average at best. Others are a lot better but obviously cost more. Generally, you get what you pay for. If restaurants / cafes are important to you, do a little research before you go. We found at least half a dozen good restaurants / cafes within 10 minutes walking distance.\nThe Hotel appears to be quite busy. There are quite a few people checking in each day but the staff were efficient and polite and nobody ever has to wait more than 5 minutes at Reception. The lifts are on the small side and they could do with another lift. Occasionally, you might have to wait a minute or so for a lift.\nOur room was a 1 bedroom suite on one of the higher floors. The cost was $280 per night which I thought was pretty good value. The room was spacious, clean, comfortable and had a kitchenette. Our room faced east which meant we had a good view (partially obstructed) of the bottom part of Central Park and the taller buildings in mid-town.\nMy only point of caution is about the Hotel's Internet room. It has 2 computers and is tiny. The Internet is free so there is high demand. There is a time limit of 30 minutes so it's a bit of a problem if you want to use it for longer than that. I found myself going down every morning before 5 am so I had the place to myself.\nAll in all, the Beacon is a very good Hotel. I stayed in one of their renovated two-room suites on one of the top floors. I even had views of the Hudson River! I could easily have spent (and was prepared to spend) $500++ for a midtown hotel and not gotten as nice a room. \nMy two-room suite was incredibly spacious, spotless and soothingly decorated. One side had a very comfortable living area with a dining table for four. The room also had a great fully equipped kitchenette with stove, refrigerator, and microwave. It was also fully stocked with plates, glasses and flatware, which I used for my take-out meal from gourmet grocer Citarella just across Broadway. There are other numerous dining options, including a great little diner adjacent to the hotel, Starbucks just a few steps away, plus plenty of restaurants of all types. Who needs a dreary hotel restaurant?!\nThe bedroom side had a very comfy king bed, large flat screen TV with a bazillion channels of cable, and iPod docking station with speakers. The bathroom was small but beautiful & functional. The all-cotton towels felt great, and there was a full array of \"emergency\" items in case you forgot your toothbrush, razor, or needed to mend something.\nAll in all, my stay greatly exceeded my expectations. The Hotel Beacon is a fabulous value for Manhattan, right smack in a great neighborhood and convenient even for my business appointment in midtown. This is now my \"go to\" hotel in NY.\nNote: The hotel is currently undergoing renovations, which always makes me shudder because of the potential noise & disruption. Don't let this scare you off. I can honestly say the renovations had no impact on my stay whatsoever. It is a no-frills establishment, has the feeling of being slightly worn. Got blank stares. Hotel doesn't have any such thing... oops. Good news is that there is a good restaurant next door that you can easily order up from so I got my soup, so perfectly fine by me.\nThere was no real work desk, I couldn't set up my laptop easily. Hotel website says \"internet access\" is included in the room description. It costs $9.95, again no big deal, but I wish hotels would clarify if it is an added cost or not, I thought it was included.\nRoom had very loud and not-very functional heating units. At first we were quite pleased as the foyer was nice and gave a good first impression. The room, however, left a lot to be desired. As we were travelling with our 5 and 7 year olds we booked a two room suite. It had two rooms and we chose to sleep on the fold out sofa bed as it was in the lounge area and it meant we could watch tv once kids had gone to bed. The sofa was incredibly uncomfortable and as a result we both had sore necks during our stay. The decor is very old fashioned and, although it was reasonably clean, it just didn't feel ''nice. The lifts were probably the worst thing about staying there as they were undergoing maintenance (apparently had been for some months!) and were very slow. More often than not we'd walk the ten floors to our room rather than wait. The staff were quite nice most of the time and the tour desk was great. \nNOW, so I don't sound like all I do is whinge, the location is great. There was nothing cooler than getting a cab and saying \"west 75th and broadway thanks'...so New York! lol It is a short walk to Central Park and Strawberry Fields, the subway and there is a big international market directly opposite. This was great, as our room had a kitchenette, we bought breakfast supplies/drinks, etc and kept them in our room. The cafe next door to the hotel is great for breakfast with friendly service. We just decided that in New York you are going to pay huge amounts of money for very little in terms of ''\u00e7lass' . We did pay a lot less than we would have done had we stayed in Times Square or the like. However, it did little to detract from our New York experience on the whole. {"ratings": {"service": 4.0, "cleanliness": 3.0, "overall": 4.0, "value": 4.0, "rooms": 4.0, "check_in_front_desk": 4.0, "business_service_(e_g_internet_access)": 3.0, "location": 3.0}, "title": "\u201cA relief to have a kitchenette and sitting room.\u201d", "text": "We did a 4 week tour of the USA over December/January 2007, with 3 older children (girl, 22, boy, 19 and boy, 18), going to San Francisco [Omni Hotel], Miami (South Beach) [Beacon Hotel], Orlando (Disneyworld, Pop Century Resort), Chicago [Drake Hotel], New York (for Christmas) [Beacon Hotel \u2013 no relation to the one in Miami], Boston [Omni Hotel], New York (again) [Roosevelt Hotel] (including New Year\u2019s Eve at the Renaissance Hotel overlooking Times Square), and a day trip to Niagara Falls. It was sometimes very cosy - sometimes downright stressful - with the kids.\nAnyway, here are my accommodation reviews. I\u2019ll mention side trips and tours too. Sometimes the accommodation was arranged through a travel agent, but on a couple of occasions I organised it direct. \nWe spent 6 nights at the Beacon Hotel in New York, including Christmas Day. We actually saw this accommodation favourably reviewed in a travel article in our local Sunday paper, and made enquiries direct as a result. It\u2019s located on Broadway on the Upper West side.\nWe had a 1 bedroom suite, which was capable of sleeping 5 - there were 2 double beds in the bedroom and a fold-out couch in the separate living area. Ultimately, we took another double room as it seemed a bit cramped to have 5 of us there, especially over Christmas. Management arranged this on the spot, and conveniently, the room was immediately next door. \nThe suite had a large living area and kitchenette, complete with large fridge, stove (hotplates and oven), cutlery, cooking utensils, crockery and glasses. Housekeeping was generally very quick with our requests for such things as extra towels, a sharp knife and cutting board, and a tray of champagne flutes.\nThere was a TV in the bedroom, along with drawers, comfy chair, wardrobe and room safe, as well as the 2 double beds (quite a large room). In the sitting room, there was another TV on a chest of drawers, the couch, a desk/table and 2 chairs, a coffee table and 2 other end tables tables, lamps, and plenty of room for a trundle bed, which management provided when the fold-out couch was found to be broken (in terms of being a fold-out bed - it was still ok as a couch). The other standard double room had 2 double beds, desk/table and chairs, comfy chair, drawers, wardrobe, safe and a small kitchenette with hotplates, crockery, etc. The bathrooms in each were a reasonable size for New York standards. There was a large laundry on a floor above us, with coin-operated washing machines and dryers (great to be able to wash clothes properly after a couple of weeks on the road). Wireless internet was $10.00 per day. The hotel is quite old (most buildings are in New York), but don\u2019t let this put you off.\nWe were particularly happy to have the living area for Christmas (I even bought a small tree and had some Christmas lights). The kitchenette and large fridge were a delight after so long in ordinary rooms with a bar fridge (if you were lucky). The best thing was the huge market across the road, which served every kind of food imaginable (from fresh fruit to sushi, gourmet cheeses and olives to TV dinners). There was a liquor store next door too. This meant that you could be completely self sufficient in your room. We had all breakfasts, several dinners and even a lunch in our room. It was a relief from having to eat out every night (and day) - we cooked up pasta in our room instead.\nAs far as the location was concerned, it depends what you want to be close to. New York is a huge city, so the Beacon is miles away from, say, Little Italy and Wall Street, the United Nations, the Guggenheim museum, or even the Empire State Building. Conversely, we walked easily to Central Park, Strawberry Fields and the Dakota, the American Museum of Natural History and even Columbus Circle. The subway was nearby, which is the best way to cheaply get around the longer distances (get a multi-journey ticket - dispatched by vending machines using a credit card on subway stations). Close by was a multiplex cinema with an IMAX theatre too. Like most big cities, you will never get a hotel in NY that is convenient to everything.\nAs for tours, we got our money\u2019s worth from a City Pass (valid for 9 days to see 6 attractions), and it saved us time when queuing for the Empire State Building. The City Pass included a boat cruise (Hudson River, Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, and the East River under the Brooklyn Bridge) which was well worth it. [Hint - trade your travel agent\u2019s voucher for the book of City Pass tickets at a less popular attraction, where the queues are shorter. For instance, at the Empire State Building, there\u2019s a huge queue to get your City Pass, then you\u2019ll have to join the back of the queue for the building itself.] The Gray Line hop-on hop-off loops (open top double-decker buses) were good too (both of these were purchased through the travel agent before we left). \nWe also did an awesome helicopter ride over Manhattan through Liberty Helicopters (the chopper takes 7 passengers plus the pilot) on Christmas Day, but that, as you can imagine, was hellishly expensive. \nThe Empire State Building is a must, but I\u2019d recommend the Top of the Rock too (the viewing decks at the top of the Rockefeller Centre). From there, you get a much better view of Central Park, plus you look south over Manhattan and see the Empire State Building too (which you can\u2019t do when you\u2019re atop it!). The big bonus is that, whilst it took about 2 hours to get to the top of the Empire State Building, there was virtually no wait to get to the Top of the Rock. We went mid-afternoon, and I stayed until the evening to get the sunset and night photos.\nThe Beacon was a great choice, for the kitchenette and for it\u2019s location across the road from the market. I\u2019d stay there again, especially if I was in Manhattan for more than a night or two.", "author": {"username": "seagullrob", "num_cities": 71, "num_helpful_votes": 180, "num_reviews": 81, "num_type_reviews": 79, "id": "30EB88A695150FDA99AB06535437DC3E", "location": "Brisbane, Queensland"}, "date_stayed": "December 2007", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 16, "date": "January 21, 2008", "id": 12834396, "via_mobile": false}

It was our first ever visit to New York, and indeed the USA. We had the taxi trip from hell (we were taken right over to the East Side, at rush hour from Penn Station, the driver thinking we were going to the Beekman, despite me giving him the address of the Beacon...) so we were a bit frazzled to say the least when we pitched up at the lobby. \nBut right from our arrival we were impressed with the friendly manner of the reception staff. Our room was on the 18th floor, one of the floors that has already been refurbished. While we were there, work was progressing on at least one other floor, but we were only aware of this when the lift stopped to allow a workman on or off. No disturbances to report. I assume that all the rooms will be refurbished eventually.\nWe were delighted with our room. We were lucky to get a corner room at the back, which meant fantastic views over to the edge of Central Park. It was plenty big enough, finished to a really high standard, with a huge bed, TV to match and a useful well-equipped kitchenette. We really can't think of anything to even mention as a downside. \nThe hotel is well-situated, the area is a lot less frantic than midtown. It's an easy walk to Central Park and with a good selection of bars, diners and restaurants nearby. The Fairway market across the street is open from 6:00am till after midnight and has everything you could possibly want in the way of food and drink. Zabars deli and H&H Bagels are a short walk up Broadway and 72nd St subway station is about 3 minutes away in the opposite direction, so great for getting around. \nI know this reads like a brochure for the hotel, but we really did find it that good - and we are fairly critical travellers not afraid to register our displeasure if things aren't up to scratch. \nWe plan to visit NYC again within the year, and having stayed at the Beacon we wouldn't entertain the idea of staying anywhere else.", "author": {"username": "bingojesus", "num_cities": 3, "num_helpful_votes": 2, "num_reviews": 3, "location": "Manchester", "id": "D9CB11799B89740D08E3BA6D54D181C9"}, "date_stayed": "June 2008", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 1, "date": "July 25, 2008", "id": 18251004, "via_mobile": false}

Not the most modern hotel I have stayed in, but there was masses of room, two TVs, a kitchenette and a view to die for, especially at night.\nContrary to previous reviews, there is a restaurant which I believe is owned by the hotel, but has a separate entrance on the ground floor. Can also recommend the Manhattan diner just up the road for breakfast or a light meal, and there are numerous restaurants in the vicinity (a comprehensive list was provided in the rooms). We had initially booked a one bedroom suite but on check-in, the desk clerk looked at our family of four and upgraded us to a two bedroom suite for no extra charge. Our suite was huge and comfortable and quite clean. You just can't beat the space for the price. The staff was friendly and helpful. We really enjoyed the restaurant upstairs at the Fairway market. The food was great and really affordable - we ended up eating there several times. There is also a Starbucks right on the corner. I loved being in this area versus the much more crowded and commercial mid-town area.\nI actually had lived at the Beacon for a year back in the late 80's and they have definately done some remodelling since that time. We were on the 8th floor and it sounded like they were doing more remodelling on the floors above us but the noise was never intrusive. There is definately a lot of street noise (hey, it's New York) and we brought \"white noise\" machines which helped a lot with sleeping.\nThe only negative experience was when we booked our return transportation to the airport through the concierge. he recommended we book a shuttle versus getting a cab since we were going to Newark. He told us, quite confidently that we would be the last stop on the shuttle and the trip would take about 45 minutes and so we had him book it for us. Well, when the shuttle arrived, the surly driver informed us that the Beacon is the first stop and the trip would take closer to an hour and a half. We ended up having to jump out in Midtown with all our luggage and hail a cab in order to get to the airport with enough time. It was no problem to get the cab driver to take us to Newark (despite what the concierge had told us). The fee for the shuttle was non-refundable so it ended up being quite expensive. {"ratings": {"service": 5.0, "cleanliness": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "rooms": 4.0, "check_in_front_desk": 5.0, "location": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cFantastic - couldn't ask for better for the price..\u201d", "text": "We arrived into New York after a long stint holidaying in Europe.. and we fell absolutley in love with this city.\nThe hotel Beacon is wonderful.. The price is great, the rooms are HUGE (in comparison to Europe), clean and tidy and it's in a great location on the lovely Upper West side, away from the tourism, hustle and bustle of \"Times Square\".There was also a HUGE laundry with lots of washes and driers which makes that horrible holiday chore not so bad..\nAlthough there was no restaurant in the hotel, it definatley wasn't needed with Fairway Market Place across the road which stocked the most superb fresh fruit and vege and a wonderful selection of hot meals to go all at a rock bottom prices, even if you choose not to buy anything from here, it surely is worthwhile just to have a look. The wine store is next door and the grocery store across the street. This is a neighborhood with real families and people living here. The neighborhood services are good because they are not catering to tourists -- there are plenty of delis, pharmacies, bookstores, etc. And just 2 blocks from the 72nd street subway. \nWe loved coming back from the crowded Times Square and Broadway area. It was a quick cab ride/subway ride back home to the hotel. It was so comforting coming back to escape all the insanity. We felt very safe and welcomed back to our neighborhood on 74th and Broadway. \nWe would highly recommend this hotel for girls weekend in New York or for families. {"ratings": {"overall": 3.0}, "title": "\u201cYes if you want space No if you want tourist location or style\u201d", "text": "The prior reviews are all pretty much on point. The review posted by \"504\" on 11/21 was right almost word for word, shabby window treatments, carpets, wallpaper, etc. Another poster described the stuff as \"faded.\"\nAll true. It depends on what you want. For us (a family of 4) the one bedroom suite was by far the largest space we stayed in: the\nbedroom was around 12 x 14 and the living room was probably 12 x 20 -- huge by Manhattan standards. (see pictures) But the place was a little worn. We're used to Marriott's and this was a couple of grades below that.\nLocation: this is not a tourist area; its more a neighborhood. I don't think theres much to do in Times Square (not into plays, ESPN, etc.) so I prefer not to stay there. This is an exiciting neighborhood with a real urban feel to it and just walking around is fun enough. The hotel is 2 blocks from the 72nd express stop on the Broadway line so its easy to get most anywhere, although at a fare of $2 - the $8 fare for a family of 4 adds up. Cab fare to the Chelsea galleries should be around $14; Canal Street should be about $18. If you want this neighborhood with some style try the On the Ave hotel 2 blocks north: more expensive and much smaller but very modern rooms.\nFood store: Best and cheapest is to shop in Fairway, the huge (by Manhattan standards) supermarket across the street or its better competitor 2 blocks north same side of the street. All the normal stuff in both stores plus tons of cheeses and prepared gourment foods. Worth a look even if you don't buy.\nRestaurants: Amsterdam and Columbus (the two street parallel to and east of Broadway) are loaded with restaurants -- walking and looking is fun by itself.\nFast Food: The two pizza places north of the hotel on the east side of Broadway were (surprisingly for NY) mediocre to bad. If you want pizza, Little Nicks (2 blocks north, west side of Broadway) was outstanding. Gigi's, about 5 blocks south, west side of Broadway, had delicious quessadillas, and the Jewish deli (3 blocks north, east side of Broadway) was mediocre to good and a little expensive for fast food", "author": {"username": "FAMILY44444", "num_cities": 31, "num_helpful_votes": 119, "num_reviews": 60, "num_type_reviews": 38, "id": "663AAF53644CD91A195036162D060B6C", "location": "latham ny"}, "date_stayed": "November 2007", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 8, "date": "November 27, 2007", "id": 11106831, "via_mobile": false}

It was the right decision. The Beacon is located in a great Upper West Side neighborhood, loaded with great stores and restaurants, and only a block from the 72nd St subway. You can be in Times Square in less than ten minutes, and from there it's easy to reach any part of NYC. This hotel is well suited to families, especially if you have a teenager that needs her privacy. Our suite was spacious by New York standards, with a well-appointed living room with a sofabed (which became my daughter's domain), a full kitchen, and a good-sized bedroom with two queen beds. We were on the 20th floor overlooking Broadway, which offered great views but was rather noisy throughout the night. The Fairway Market across the street is a great place to shop, but they take deliveries around the clock, and the trucks idle the whole time. If you're a light sleeper, demand a room at the back. I thought our suite was very nicely decorated, with no signs of wear and tear whatsoever. The beds were comfy, all the appliances worked, and we had plenty of towels and kitchen utensils. Although the traffic noise was constant, we never heard a peep from our neighbors, no running water, flushing, TV, nothing. The elevators were a bit slow but we never had to wait longer than 2 minutes. The housekeepers were friendly and gave us whatever we asked for no questions asked, but some of the people at the front desk could use a refresher course in customer service, or maybe a surgical procedure to remove their attitude. But there were also some very friendly clerks who went out of their way to help. Getting back to the Fairway, this is an incredible market, with an amazing selection of meats, cheeses, produce, and deli items, all very reasonably priced. The store is open until 1:00am, so my advice is go late at night, because in the afternoon and early evening \nthe aisles are packed to the gills. If you're not into grocery shopping, there are dozens of great restaurants within a five minute walk. The Beacon is an ideal choice for people on a budget: for the price of an ordinary room in one of the big chain hotels in Times Square, you get a suite with a full kitchen, and room to relax. When you're tired from sightseeing all day, it doesn't matter if the comforter doesn't match the walls or if the sofa cushion design is a little worn. A USA Today newspaper is delivered to the door every morning, which is nice to have. \n The only real downside to the visit was the elevators. In the past the elevators have been a little slow, but of no concern, but this time the wait time for elevators was sometimes quite long. There are notes saying they are working on them and directions on accessing the service elevators, but even that isn't always a help. Fortunately we were only on the seventh floor, so walking down was always an option, but only a necessity once. Hopefully they will get this improved, but even as it is, I'd stay there again. \n Locationwise, this place is wonderfully situated. THAT WAS GREAT.\nThe only caution i have is beware of the locals on the elevators, very rude. But it is NY.\nAlso, the hotel is a bit dated. Meaning the wall paper is old and so is some of the furniture. But in no way is it unclean or not comfortable. I felt this have the place some character. Nice break from the cookie cutter world we tend to live in these days.\nThere is a laundry room on the 7th floor, containing 8 very clean washers and 8 well kept dryers. Each cycle cost $1.75.\nThe location is awesome. 1,2,3 train is only a short 2 block walk. Fairway grocery is across the street, with excellent fresh produce and just about anything one would want. I read about the prices being high. NOT TRUE. With the kitchen in the room we saved big $$ eating breakfast, lunch, and a couple of dinners in the room.\nEats- Big Nick's on broadway is a must. Their menu is extensive. We don't eat meat and were delighted to find well over 20 vegetarian offerings. Also try the Pizza shop on Amsterdam, something and Peppers, can't recall the full name.\nThe park is about a 10 minute walk each way and worth it. For you will pass some truly beautiful brownstones. The Museum of Natural History is only about a 15 minute walk. For those of you with young kids in the park just after 81st street you will find the Dinana Ross Playground. Sand, fountain, swings (toddler and tire), and two huge playsets. Like every park in the city it's fenced in and well shaded.\nWe did not use the wireless network, so can't comment either way. \nThe next time we go to NYC it will once again be at the Hotel Beacon. The rooms are big by NYC standards - my kids had plenty of room to spread out their games.\nThe neighborhood is great - a real residential neighborhood, as opposed to the Times Square area or the Wall Street area where we sometimes stay. There are plenty of markets, restaurants and stores at all price levels and tastes. We had breakfast a few times at the Tasty Cafe near the subway station (Broadway and 72nd, I think). This is a counter service place, but the food is great and quick, and there is a used book seller that sets up his stand right outside the door who encouraged the kids to look through his wares.\nBecause the neighborhood is not as crowded and fast-paced as Midtown, we did not have to hold tightly onto our kids. The could enjoy looking around at a relaxed pace. Also, there is a fun playground with a Western theme at Amsterdam and 77th that my kids wanted to return to again and again.\nThe concierge staff were very helpful. (They were the ones who directed us to the playground). Anything they couldn't answer, they looked up quickly for us. We didn't use them for anything high-end, like getting theater tickets, so don't know how they would do with that. \nA small thing, but a nice surprise was the toiletries in the room. Most hotels have a sign saying to ask the staff if there is anything you have forgotten, but Hotel Beacon anticipated everything for us, which is much better. The toiletries included things like cotton swabs and a toothbrush!\nWe have stayed at the Hotel Excelsior in the same neighborhood. Rooms are small; or the carpeting might be a little threadbare;\nor the elevators will be slow; or the staff might be rude. Or some combination of the above. It's simply what you have to expect in New York.\nBy those standards, the Beacon was fantastic for me. I only stayed one night, so I didn't have time to use my fully equipped kitchenette\n(a great feature). OK, the elevators were very slow, but I only experienced one wait longer than a couple of minutes. \nMy room was big -- much larger than other rooms I have had in the city. I lucked out with a 19th floor room on the southeastern corner,\nwith eastward views of the famous Dakota apartment building and a sliver of Central Park, and southern views toward Columbus Circle.\nThe room's furnishings weren't up-to-date and there were a few cigarette burns in the carpet. So what? If you want a \"design\" hotel you can look elsewhere. The a/c worked great, the bed was comfortable, the linens were clean, and so on. The room was huge and I had a sitting area with a table. This hotel even has a concierge, which is very rare for New York hotels in the moderate price range.\nThe Fairway supermarket across the street is amazing, and I am running out of superlatives to describe the Citarella gourmet market next door (even the website will make a foodie drool). A few blocks away you can shop at the famous Zabar's. One New Yorker (a client I visited while in town) told me this is the best area in Manhattan for food shopping. So you literally can cook gourmet meals in your room -- or simply reheat some of the wonderful goodies from across the street. That will stretch your dining budget and allow you to splurge on other meals while you're out on the town.\nI met a friend for dinner and spent $160 (for two) at an Argentinean steak restaurant. It was a good meal, but I would have had just as much fun shopping for gourmet food and wine with my friend, and dining in my room with its city views. And we would have spent half as much.\nEat breakfast at Big Nick's, a 24-hour Greek diner just up Broadway on the west side of the street. I enjoyed a great breakfast at an outdoor table. Being that it's a one star hotel, I expected it to be decent for the value but not much more.\nWe were wrong! We ended up loving the Beacon and have found \"our\" place to stay when we're in New York. The one bedroom suite was huge, had a kitchenette, was very clean. As you've heard from others, the neighborhood could not be better. The Upper West side has a great NY feel--visiting Times Square was a lot of fun, but I wouldn't want to be plopped right in the middle of it in a cramped and overpriced hotel room.\nSome other plusses--the Starbucks right next door, the great market across the street (that incidentally all you lymies like my husband had tons of English stuff including every English candy bar you could want!), was a five minute walk to the subway, and a ten minute walk to Central Park. My husband's a runner and ran every day there. \nThe hotel was much nicer than I expected. I'd say that unless you're a high maintenance traveler with expectations of people waiting on you hand and foot like in a chain hotel or the more expensive variety, you'll like it. No they didn't call a cab for us (we didn't ask). It's on Broadway for God's sake, it takes like 30 seconds to hail a cab to take you to the airport! Yes, we carried our luggage up, no there isn't room service (although a restaurant delivers there that we didn't use) You get the gist--it's a one star hotel so it isn't going to be perfect. The staff however was fine, no complaints whatsoever.\nAnyway, bottom line is that for the value, it was a great experience. By the time we left it felt like our little home away from home. We're going back in May with family and after this test run, we will always recommend the Beacon.\nBy the way, price out a one bedroom vs. a standard room--it wasn't much more and was so nice to have a separate living area. It is a reasonable walk from Lincoln Center, convenient to a good subway line (with direct connection to Penn Station), and surrounded by a residential neighborhood, so area restaurants have to stand or fall based on return business rather than a convenient location for tourists. The kitchenette, while very small, had a stove, oven, toaster, coffeemaker, and refrigerator, and a basic set of dishes and cookware (probably a microwave too, but we didn't use one so I don't remember), and there is a very extensive grocery store right across the street, so it is quite feasible to make your own simple breakfasts and pack lunches if you want to ease the financial stress of doing things in Manhattan. We were on the 16th floor with a basic city view - nothing special at all. No complaints there, as that is not a big deal for us. Ammenities within the hotel itself are minimal, but I did read there is a gym attached to it or something now (ground floor) for a $5.00 per use fee. With all the walking and carrying packages, you won't need it ! \nMy only \"complaint\" if you will is I could hear the people talking and their TV in the next room. The walls are on the thin side. {"ratings": {"cleanliness": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "rooms": 4.0, "service": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cAn Excellent Value with a Great Location\u201d", "text": "My spouse and I rely on Trip Advisor for guidance in selecting hotels when we travel, so we spent many hours reading others' reviews and studying the options before we chose the Beacon Hotel. We've traveled from the West Coast to New York City many times (our son lives in NYC), but, until this trip, we have never been satisfied with the lodging we've chosen.\nWe were very pleased overall with this hotel. We stayed 4 nights and were able to get a daily rate of $180 (plus the taxes, etc.) \nWe hoped to avoid the noisest and most congested parts of Manhattan and wanted to be near the 1 subway line. (I suppose it is 2 1/2 blocks from the hotel to the subway entrance, but it feels like a walk of one block). Other positives of our stay at the Beacon included:\n1. The location is superb - many others have covered this in their reviews.\n2. The hotel was very clean.\n3. The staff was friendly and professional. (This fact bears mentioning, because it is often not the case, in my experience; even in more expensive hotels in New York.)\n4. Our room was quite large by New York standards. (We had a standard room with 2 double beds and a kitchenette.)\n5. The room was remarkably quiet and peaceful (more on that below).\n6. The maid service was excellent. The first day we slept in due to a late arrival and the time change. We didn't leave the room until late afternoon. Nonetheless, the room was cleaned cheerfully at that hour. \n7. The kitchenette was adequately equipped and will allow you to have some meals in, if you wish. Fairway Market across the street has great produce (grocery items are overpriced) and it remains open until 1a.m., I think. Other markets are close by.\n8. We stayed during the heat of mid-summer. The air conditioning in our room was excellent. The room had its own heating/cooling unit. We could easily set the temperature (within one degree) and got nearly instant response. Room units do make a little noise, but it wasn't a problem (and, alas, I'm oversensitive to noise). \nWe knew we would be arriving late so we phoned early that day to request a quiet, non-smoking room, located high up in the hotel. (I also indicated that preference on the online reservation, but experience has taught me that often does no good at all.) The phone call worked: Our request was honored perfectly. We were on the 18th floor at the end of the hall and the entire floor was non-smoking. It was so nice to be able to return to the hotel to a quiet, cool room.\nThe hotel was old, but our room was upgraded substantially. Nice tile in the bathroom; new cupboards in the kitchenette. Yes, the carpet was old and the bedspreads looked as unappetizing as most hotel bedspreads, but we felt very comfortable in this room.\nNice folks in the lobby arranged a shuttle for us to Kennedy Airport. (This required cash. We were able to pay for almost everything else - except cabs - by credit card.) For those who don't know, you can travel from Kennedy or LaGuardia (I'm not sure about Newark) TO Manhattan for a fixed cab fee; but the trip BACK to the airport from Manhattan is on the meter if you take a cab.\nSmall problems: \n1. Another recent reviewer mentioned the raised marble step into the bathroom. This is not a good situation at all. We placed a stack of cardboard on the floor in front of this to prevent injury. (No joke, I'm sure this has caused broken or painfully bruised toes.)\n2. The beds were hard; not firm, but hard! This is a problem in lots of hotels (perhaps because this makes the mattresses last longer). I had to strip the bed, double up the bedspread and put it under the mattress pad and bottom sheet. That helped a little but was still not adequate. I realize this will not be a problem for all people. \n3. A nitpick, I suppose, but I wish management would allow late check outs. They were inflexible on this; which is ridiculous, because they obviously can not clean all the rooms at the same time. Also, they require you to check out in person in the lobby, without adequate staff. In my experience, most hotels provide some form of express check out (often through the TV's). Instead, we had to wait in a long line to check out. \nOverall, we were very happy with our stay at the Beacon Hotel and plan to stay there on future visits. After reading all the reviews here I was a bit fearful that the hotel would be a bit run down. We did not feel that was the case at all.", "author": {"username": "", "id": "", "location": ""}, "date_stayed": "July 2006", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 18, "date": "July 16, 2006", "id": 5472451, "via_mobile": false}

{"ratings": {"cleanliness": 5.0, "value": 5.0, "overall": 5.0, "rooms": 4.0, "service": 5.0}, "title": "\u201cLocation, Location, Location - Hotel Beacon is where it's at\u201d", "text": "Spent three days and nights in NYC (6/22 - 6/24) with my wife and three teenage daughters who were all seeing the Big Apple for the very first time. The Hotel Beacon was an excellent launching point for our daily and nightly journeys all over Manhattan.\nLocation is just about fifty yards from one of the main subway stops, 72nd and Broadway, and for seven dollars a day (until 3 am) or twenty four dollars for seven days, you can travel unlimited on the subways. We took the subway everywhere and felt very same at all hours of the day and night.\nSpecifics about the hotel:\nGreat points: LOCATION. Two blocks west of Central Park. Great neighborhood. Fine breakfast/lunch cafe next door, full liquor store/wine shoppe next door the other way and directly across the street from the Fairway, one of the few full service grocery stores in all of Manhattan. Also across the street from a parking garage which is $31 a day with a hotel stamp - otherwise it would be $40 a day. Rooms were bigger than I was expecting for NYC. We did have five people with each of my daughters agreeing to sleep on the floor on a sleeping bag one night each. We never told the hotel we had five people and never received any hassles. Concierge has great map of Manhattan and Subway system that was our bible to the city. We could get anywhere with our map and the subway and a little help from a lot of friendly New Yorkers. Kitchenette was handy. Refrigerated worked great - don't turn it up to the top setting unless you want your Milk and soda to freeze like ours did. One of my daughters used the stove top to cook some rice and we also used the toaster. It's a little hard for me to say the price was GREAT but compared to all the other hotels I researched, it was a bargain. Total Bill for three days including 30 minutes in the internet cafe ($5) and one day of in room high speed internetn service ($10) was $675 - hotel was $210 a night plus four more taxes added in. We found the concierge, front desk, and other staff members very helpful at all times and would not hesitate recommending the Hotel Beacon to anyone else\nCouple of small nits - I understand some of the concerns about the A/C. We kept it on High the whole time and were comfortable most of the time and it was in the mid 80's and humid in NYC during our stay. There is a small marble ledge leading up into the bathroom that I absolutely smashed my left foot into one morning. They should have some type of leveling plate on that. We just put a towel over it the rest of our stay so nobody else mashed a toe. Bathroom didn't have a fan and had poor ventilation so no to get too graphic here, we would send people to the 2nd floor public bathrooom if they had any real \"business\" to do as the whole room would otherwise smell. This was not a big inconvenience given all of the postives.\nSummary of our trip, in just 2.5 days we did more than five people humanly should including riding the Staten Island Ferry (it's free) past the Statue of LIberty, going up in the Empire State Building (not worth the cost or time), shopping and eating in Chinatown, visiting Ground Zero, now just called the \"WTC site\", saw both \"Chicago\" (fantastic) and \"The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee\" (hilarious) on Broadway, ate at a friends deli on Park Avenue, the girls shopped until they dropped at Century 21, H & B, Bloomingdales, Macy's, and all the wholesale shops on Broadway in the Garment District, ate great Pizza at three places, visited Times Square (our kid's favorite place) and sampled the night life in the West Village on Bleeker Street as well as getting crazy at Hogs and Heifers which is supposed to be the place that gave rise to the Coyote Ugly practice of dancing on the bar. Wild, wild place. Thank you everybody who bought us shots (I think) although staying out until 4 am made our ride back to Mississippi the next day a little more challenging.\nOverall we had a fantastic time and I thank Trip Advisor and all the other people who give their input into helping to make the trip such a success. He almost turned inside out with excitement when he saw their collection and his mother and I were almost as pleased with the Beacon. It is a perfect home away from home for familties.\nPROS:\n - Easy walk from Central Park and the Museum, even for a 3 year old, plus a very nice public playground along the way. Safe, tree-lined streets. \n - $220 a night for a suite with a small kitchen. You can put the little one to bed, close the door, and the adults can have a drink or snack, or watch TV without disturbing him.\n - Fairway Market across the street. You can buy anything there ( I think they are open 24 hr). You can save major money and avoid the hassle of eating in a restaurant with a toddler and prepare all you need in your own kitchen.\n - I went out to buy a bottle of wine and strolled around the neighborhood a little. As other reviewers have said you do feel like a local. There are newsstands, curbside book vendors (at least on Sunday), and many small shops, bars and restaurants. Many trees, too.\n - The hotel lobby is clean and inviting, the staff was polite and efficient, we requested wineglasses be brought to the room and they arrived quickly. \nCONS:\n - None to speak of, really. Some might find the decor and architecture a bit dated but it is an old building and I found it reminiscent of the classy old days of NYC. Everything was very clean and no bugs, bed or otherwise.\n - My son had one disapointment, though. We went to the museum first and when we were walking into the hotel later he asked in a loud voice \"DO THEY HAVE DINOSAURS IN HERE TOO?\" He now thinks all big buildings in NYC should have dinosaur skeletons in them. I was referred to this hotel by a friend who had stayed there 6 times and also the Flight Centre. The photos do not do the hotel justice. It looks quite old in the photos but the room is very spacious and though the furniture is a bit dated, the beds were comfy and everything was clean. This hotel has everything you need. The kitchenette is handy, we had breakfast every morning purchased from across the street at Fairway. 72nd st station was a few metres away (which we missed the first day there!) and that takes you everywhere. The subway is easy to use. We had a weekly metro card which you can top up, with trips anywhere costing something like $2.20/trip. There are also many, many laundrettes around the hotel. There's also a camera shop around the corner where we dumped our photos from our memory card onto CD at. We couldn't find this facility anywhere! The only thing I would strongly recommend is checking out early. We went down 45 mins before and the lobby was packed. This hotel is in a great location. It is easy to walk around the area and to get to other places. Our first day we walked down to Fifth Ave which wasn't too far away. We highly recommend this hotel. {"ratings": {"cleanliness": 3.0, "value": 1.0, "overall": 2.0, "rooms": 2.0, "service": 3.0}, "title": "\u201cDepressing Decor, Great Location.\u201d", "text": "In my opinion, the only thing the Beacon Hotel has going for it is it's excellent location and friendly staff. The Hotel itself is in desperate need of a facelift. The rooms are antiquated and are painted a disturbingly gloomy shade of pink. The air conditioning system belongs in the National HIstory Museum and the bathrooms are uncomfortably small. To best conjure the perfect image, think dodgy seaside B&B in a backwash town circa 1970's and you have the Beacon interior. Do not expect 'any' of the usual perks and luxury you would usually expect from such a costly hotel. Although shabby, the rooms are clean and a newspaper is delivered, roughly every second day, however that is the extent of it. \nOn the upside, the Beacon Hotel is situated beside Filene's Basement Department Store and adjacent to 72nd Subway station. I urge you to utilize the subway, great efforts have been made to make it safe. My mother is in her 70's and is happy to use it alone (during daylight hours). The Hotel receptionist will furnish you with a good map free of charge.\nIn real terms, it's hard to get great accomodation in NY unless you are willing to bend your platinum card, however, it is really not good enough to pretend that this hotel is acceptable under modern day value for money standards. The 72nd street express subway station is only 2 1/2 short blocks away. In one stop, you can be at Times Square. The area around the Beacon is easy to explore by foot. There are actually signs warning drivers not to honk their horns, and it works! The area feels like a neighborhood (unlike Times Square and Midtown). The American Museum of Natural History is an easy walk; and the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a slightly longer, but enjoyable, walk to the east side of Central Park. In the standard room, the kitchenette consists of a half-sized refrigerator, a two-burner stovetop (with teakettle), a sink, toaster, and a microwave. We ate H&H bagels every morning in our room (just 5 blocks up Broadway for some of the best bagels), and we ate dinner in our room. We saved a lot of money eating in, and it was easier for our kids to relax at the end of the day in the room rather than having to behave at a restaurant. We were there for 4 nights Feb 9-13 2006 and were thrilled to experience the biggest ever recorded snowfall in New York - 27 inches in Central Park!\nHad researched many hotels and reviews before booking and can confirm Beacon is one of best deals. Hotel clean, warm, heating works! Rooms massive - 2 double beds. Powerful shower with plenty of hot water at midnight when we arrived. Kitchenette etc all as per other reviews, great! Reception staff accommodating. We arrived late and although I had previously e-mailed to request non-smoking room these are allocated on arrival so we had smoking room 1st night. However, there was no evidence of its use as a smoking room - smell and condition of room no different to non-smoking room we were swiftly moved to for rest of our stay. So if arriving late would advise telephone beforehand. Don't use hotel phones - we didn't, but got a $5(\u00a33) phonecard which gave us over 3 hours uk landline calltime! You can use card in public hotel phones on 2nd floor. Once you have dialled number, you are told how much calltime you have. \nAlso bad idea to order takeout - massive pizza but as we'd ordered 2 bill was also massive! \nCitypass good value, everything in New York a must and of course impossible in one visit! Some of best times we had were in Manhatten Diner a couple of streets up from hotel on Broadway. Excellent food, value and well frequented by local residents!\nSubway great, we got 7 day pass as good value. Covers all of New York City. We had no problems using it late night as plenty of people still about. We also used AirTrain/subway link to travel to/from hotel/airport. No problems with traffic and cheapest transfer fare. However, elevators/lifts for AirTrain but not at other subway stations. Need cash for subway tickets as credit cards can only be verified if you are U.S. resident. \nClothes not generally cheap, best value Gap, Old Navy and Dave's (where you can get Levi's for under \u00a320). The latter 2 shops are virtually opposite each other on 6th Avenue (of the Americas) at 16th St. \nI managed to break my wrist ice-skating in Central Park but this didn't mar our stay. Lenox Hill Hospital staff great, efficient, just make sure you have travel insurance! Preferably with an office address in U.S. then hospital can bill them direct!\nGo and enjoy!", "author": {"username": "", "id": "", "location": ""}, "date_stayed": "February 2006", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 23, "date": "March 14, 2006", "id": 4616165, "via_mobile": false}
{"ratings": {"cleanliness": 4.0, "value": 4.0, "overall": 5.0, "rooms": 4.0, "service": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cGreat Hotel, great location\u201d", "text": "Had no hesitation about booking this hotel again for my second trip to New York. The room was clean, comfortable and, from my experience, quite large. The bathroom could be considered small, but I did not find this a problem. The room also contains a small fully equiped kitchenette area, with fridge, microwave and a two ring stove top (including a coffee maker and tea/coffee which was topped up daily). \nWireless internet is also available, but this carries a daily charge if used. The access code needs to be obtained from reception and it changes daily. \nNew flatscreen TV in the room, with a huge selection of free TV channels. Also, the usual selection of pay tv. But why bother, if you want to pay to see movies then there are several cinema multiplexes within a few blocks walking distance from the hotel (and cheaper too).\nAs for hotel's location, couldn't be better, in a residential area on the Upper West Side. Only two stops from Penn station on the express subway line and one from Times Square. The hotel is only 1-2 blocks from the 72nd street subway station. Across the street is the excellent Fairway 24hr supermarket and a few blocks away is probably the best deli in New York, Zabars. Also, within a stone's throw from the hotel entrance are numerous Starbucks, cafes, diners and restaurants. \nAll in all a great place to stay. There is a very well stocked wine store two doors away and an excellent 24hr supermarket straight across the road. But after having read the positive reviews we decided to go back and we are more than glad that we did so. The stay already started great when upon an e-mail send to the Beacon a while before our trip, we got a room as requested on one of the upper floors to the back of the hotel. Our room was on the 18th floor with a great view (we even caught a glimpse of Central Park). It was spacious and as many other reviewers we enjoyed the small kitchenette. The staff was always helpful and friendly. One morning we told them that our TV did not work properly and when we arrived back in our room in the afternoon it was fixed. \nWhat\u2019s also great, is the location. The next subway station is just two short blocks away (Central Park and Museum of Natural History only 3 blocks) and the neighbourhood offers lots of nice small affordable restaurants and shops (incl. supermarkets and the usual suspects in men\u2019s and women\u2019s apparel for a little pre-dinner shopping ;-)). After a day of sightseeing in hectic and noisy \u201cdowntown\u201d Manhattan, we enjoyed to step from the subway and stroll around Broadway, Amsterdam and Columbus Ave. For breakfast we can not only recommend the upstairs bakery of the Fairway supermarket (as many other reviewers) but also the Viand Caf\u00e9 (connected to the hotel). From Monday through Friday they offer breakfast specials which we found reasonable priced and of good quality. \nWe really hope that the Beacon team keeps the standard and we will definitely choose the Beacon again.", "author": {"username": "", "id": "", "location": ""}, "date_stayed": "May 2005", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 24, "date": "June 26, 2005", "id": 3612295, "via_mobile": false}
{"ratings": {"cleanliness": 2.0, "value": 3.0, "overall": 3.0, "rooms": 3.0, "service": 4.0}, "title": "\u201cGood Location, OK Value\u201d", "text": "We (family of 4 with teenagers) stayed here for 5 nights- May 31-June 5th. The location is good if you want to get out of the hustle and bustle of midtown. It is a very short walk to the subway( I was expecting longer blocks). The area around the hotel seemed very safe even late at night walking back from the sub. Our room was a 1 bedroom suite located on the 11th floor at the back of the hotel. We didn't have a \"good view\", but that was ok since we didn't have to listen to the noise from the street. We had a LARGE storage closet located in the hallway with a hanging space at the rear, along with 2 other closets, one in the hall and one in bedroom. The bedroom had 2 double beds, and the living area had a regular size sofa bed, even though we were told it was a queen sofa. There was more than enough room for our clothes, etc. Having a kitchen was great, especially when traveling with teenagers who want to eat in the middle of the night. After checking into hotel, we walked across street to the Fairway Market and stocked up on snacks, drinks, and breakfast food. However, I don't recommend going there during the typical rush hour after work, it was horrible to try to find your items and check out. I had read one complaint about roaches, so I bought a box of large storage zip bags and stored all our food in them, along with keeping all food/drink items in the refrigerator (it was about 3/4 size of a regular refrigerator). The hotel supplies the dishwashing liquid, so I washed the things (glasses, flatware and a couple bowls/plates) I thought we would use and kept those in the refrigerator also. Turns out that the only bugs(2 small roaches) we saw were both in the bathroom.\nWe found the employees to be very helpful and quick to respond to request. We had to call once because the room above ours had some kind of leak over our tub area, and the maintenance man was up to our room in less than 5 minutes. They called us back to report what they had found and corrected. We were constantly asking for more bath towels, and they were always delivered in less than 5 minutes. Several times, we just left a note for the housekeeper to leave extra towels, and she left more than what we actually used.\nThe negative things about the room was the bathroom was not as clean as it could have been. There was a lot of mold in the tub--around the caulking where the tile met the tub, and in the corners going up the tile walls. So as a result, it made the whole tub/shower area feel dirty. The bathroom itself was very small; you cannot have more than 1 person at a time in there. The furniture in the living area was very old, and the upholstery was stained and grimy looking. The lighting was not as bright as it could have been, so we kept the windows wide open to help with the light. We paid $235 + taxes per night, which I thought was a little high, but with the extra space, it was worth it in the end. We had friends who stayed in the Times Square area last summer, who paid $195 + taxes per night, and their room was TINY. \nWe liked the location, the restaurants in the area were good, and would consider staying here again if I knew the furnture would be in better shape, along with a cleaner bathroom.", "author": {"username": "meikner", "num_cities": 20, "num_helpful_votes": 36, "num_reviews": 27, "num_type_reviews": 19, "id": "7F63B6B3C377B7569CB49E83FC56B271", "location": "Humble, Texas"}, "date_stayed": "May 2005", "offering_id": 93338, "num_helpful_votes": 13, "date": "June 7, 2005", "id": 3538038, "via_mobile": false}

The short summary is this hotel is junk for a couple, maybe suited to a family. It was my first trip to NYC and I got a cheap rate but to be honest would never stay here again, and would gladly pay more on my next visit for a better hotel.\nLobby: nice lobby. As soon as you get out to your floor the wallpaper shows its age, the doors to each room much be at least 20 years old (just the locks upgraded to a keycard system).\nRoom: the rooms are BIG, thats the only good point, if you have a child or another person it would be very easy to live comfortablt. It also has a mini kitchinette and microwave, which again is good if you want to save $, but when you are out and about in NYC, it's not worth catching the subway back from times square to heat up something..its new york..pretzels are $1, enjoy the city. Furthermore, there are alot of places around the hotel which have good food at all hours.\nLocation: upper west side: subway is approx 3 min walk to 72nd street, then you can catch an express train to times square. (one stop). There is a fairway supermarket across the road for water, snacks if you want. Plenty of restraunts around the neighbourhood. It's quieter than the midtown hustle and bustle which is sometimes a good thing.\nOther expieriences: When we got into the room, the safe didnt work. They sent up a tech who replaced the batteries. Unpack and settle down a bit, then we notice the bathroom has not been properly cleaned from the previous occupant (bins are unemptied, no shampoos or soaps). Called housekeeping to tell them, they said they would send someone up right away. As we were waiting, I wanted to turn the heater on, the heater didnt work. \nAfter 50 mins of waiting and calling housekeeping again, I was annoyed I wasted this time on my first trip to NYC and told them to forget it. I didn't even ask for a room change as the staff just didnt seem interested. Figured I would enjoy the great city and just sleep in this hotel.\nNext day early morning my room was made AND CLEANED and stocked. However I just bared it with the lack of heating.\nInternet: they offer internet, I checked mail the first day after being told to go to level 2 computer room. The next day at 1am I also wanted to check my email/flights, when I went to the front desk, this time I was told they charge $5 per half hour?? When I mentioned yesterday I was not asked, they chap said ok thats fine then he unlocked the pc room for me. So I don't know if he wanted to pocket $5 or what the system is.\nConclusion: This hotel is OK if you can get it for $125 a night..its not worth $1 more.\nThe only saving grace is if you have a family, then I can see how the kitchenette may benefit if you want do some cooking in the room. But for a couple there for 3 nights wanting to explore all of manhattan, this hotel is not all that its cracked up to be. {"ratings": {"overall": 3.0}, "title": "\u201cThe Beacon was grand!\u201d", "text": "I stayed in the Beacon Hotel for 5 nights in May 2005. Our party was two adults and one child. We had requested a double room. The room consisted of two queen beds and was huge!!It had closet with an electronic safe (very handy). There was a kitchenette with micorwave, cooker hob and a fridge. Great to have with a 3 year old in tow. The bathroom was grand. The toilet flooded once and got blocked a second time but the staff were down asap to unblock and clean up. The cleaning of the room was brilliant, they came every day. The AC was great. The only drawback was the noise from the traffic outside. We were on the 8th floor. I was up at 5 or 6 every morning with the noise but there is lots to do in nyc so I didnt mind too much.\nWhen you exit the hotel turn left and continue on to subway station on 72nd street, dead handy - goes straight to Times Square. There is also a great funky clothes store near the station, Urban Outfitters, cute stuff you dont get in Ireland. Also if you exit the hotel and turn right and walk down to 79th street you will find Feline's Basement shop, good bargains.\nThere is also a great market directly opposite the hotel for supplies.\nAll in all the hotel was great. Its my first vist to New York and when I go back which I definitely will. I will stay here again. The staff are friendly and helpful. The rooms are clean and spacious. (think Holiday Inn standard) with the added bonus of a large fridge and two ring cooker, microwave and coffee maker. Although we didn\u2019t do any cooking it was great for making drinks and keeping drinks and fruit in. The Beacon is in a great location on Broadway but away from the tourists. This is a residential area but it is lively with a real New York buzz to it. The area felt really safe in fact the whole of Manhattan did. There are coffee shops, clothes shops, numerous restaurants, bookshops which stay open until 10.00pm! 10mins to Central Park, 10mins to the Natural History Museum (a must if you have kids, especially the planetarium), 1min to the nearest subway (72nd St) which will take you right down to the bottom of Manhattan and over to Brooklyn without having to change trains. The famous Zabars is just up the road but I have to make a special mention of Fairways Food market which is opposite the Beacon. You can get everything you may need foodwise there and more. If the weather is nice get a picnic from the Deli and head for Central Park. And they have a great cafe upstairs where you can get a good breakfast (my kids loved the pancakes with maple syrup) but at 5.30 it turns into a restaurant with candles and tablecloths.
